dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A spacious 2nd floor of faux paint and crushed sea shells A TV REMOTE with a shit-ton of buttons. Behind it, a FLAT SCREEN squawks to an empty room. A SNACK PLATE and EMPTY CUP sit atop a kitchen island. PUSHING PAST a BIN of CHILDREN’S TOYS, down a hallway fil with STEAM...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE STEAM swirls around the spa-like interior. A PLASTIC COMB rests between HIS AND HER SINKS, under EMP TOWEL RACKS. Buried within the aquatic echo-chamber, FAINT CRUNCHING. The faucet SQUEAKS OFF. DRIPS resonate from behind the shower curtain. Through a cracked window, an OCEAN BREEZE swallows the steam. A CAR STEREO attacks and decays. Then quiet. The shower SQUEAKS ON and the STEAM retakes the room. ANOTHER NOISE. The water SQUEAKS OFF and the shower curta yanks back, revealing a BEARDED MAN (36) with sun-baked s alarmed but motionless. Muffled, through walls: TIRES ON GRAVEL. THE THUMP OF CAR DOORS. ON THE BEARDED MAN: FIGHT-OR-FLIGHT...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A FAMILY spills through the door (FATHER, MOTHER, weighed down with GROCERIES and TWO YOUNG DAUGHTERS running wild) wonderful cacophony disrupting the quiet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The FATHER places REALTOR’S HOUSE KEYS on the island coun beside the SNACK PLATE...

dialogues.speaker: FATHER
dialogues.text: Hey! QUIET...  The WIFE turns from the THERMOSTAT and hushes the kids. The TV IS AUDIBLE. The Father sidesteps into the hallway, seeing DISSIPATING STEAM DRIFT FROM THE BATHROOM.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Honey. AMANDA. Take them back to the car. Call 911. The Wife corrals the girls as the Father DRAWS FROM A WOO KNIFE BLOCK SET, creeping down the hallway...

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: (urgent whisper) Eric! What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: FATHER
dialogues.text: (bluffing a threat)

dialogues.speaker: DAUGHTER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: There’s a dog?! Nearing the bathroom threshold, the Father tightens a two handed grip around his weapon, realizing he’s selected a ROUNDED STEEL SHARPENER from the knife block. HE SLIPS TO THE HARD WOOD FLOOR, landing torso upright wi SHARP BREATH. A Daughter breaks free as the Mother fumbles her purse. The Father’s lower vantage reveals A TRAIL OF WET FOOTPRI LEADING TO THE BACK OF THE HOUSE. His daughter runs past GIGGLING, following the footprints

dialogues.speaker: FATHER
dialogues.text: ELLA! NO! Dammit...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her Father in pursuit, the Daughter crosses the carpeted and pokes her head through an open window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FROM ABOVE: The Bearded Man runs naked clutching a wad of clothes, disappearing into an alleyway.  10 ON THE WINDOW: The daughter watches nonchalantly until he father scoops her up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Obscured through CLOTHESLINES and fencing, the Bearded Ma jogs to a stop and steps into his worn khakis. CLACK. He squats and rises, inspecting his PLASTIC COMB, now speckled with sand. He blows it clean.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dressed but damp, the Bearded Man drips a trail up the sa walkway, anxiously combing his hair. He moves against bea traffic past modern condos, older bungalows and monstrous resort homes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Bearded Man sheaths his comb and turns down a walkway leading to a SMALL TOWN POLICE STATION.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Bearded Man opens the door for an exiting PATROL OFFI returning a nod and weaving his way past RECEPTION to a FEMALE OFFICER (55) eating an egg sandwich at her desk.

dialogues.speaker: BEARDED MAN
dialogues.text: If you get any calls about 104 St. Louis... She looks up from her desk, chewing.

dialogues.speaker: BEARDED MAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: -..it was me.

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE OFFICER
dialogues.text: Good morning... He fails to read her expectant look. FEMALE OFFICER (CONT’D) (relenting) I think I just heard that go out. She motions to a nearby DISPATCHER who removes his HEADSE  FEMALE OFFICER (CONT’D) Dale, who picked up the ten- fourteen?

dialogues.speaker: DISPATCH OFFICER
dialogues.text: Maucieri and Lutz. She picks a WALKIE TALKIE from her desk, waving it.

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE OFFICER
dialogues.text: May I?

dialogues.speaker: DISPATCH OFFICER
dialogues.text: (replacing headset) Yes ma'am.

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE OFFICER
dialogues.text: (into walkie) County five one nine? She deadpans the Bearded Man. He returns an anxious stare

dialogues.speaker: MALE VOICE, (OVER WALKIE STATIC)
dialogues.text: Go for county five one nine.

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE OFFICER
dialogues.text: Make that ten fourteen on St. Louis a ten-thirty-one. Repeat, ten- thirty-one, same address.

dialogues.speaker: MALE VOICE, (OVER WALKIE STATIC)
dialogues.text: Roger. She sets the walkie down and gestures to the untouched ha of her sandwich. The Bearded Man shakes ‘no’.

dialogues.speaker: BEARDED MAN
dialogues.text: Is there anything I should do? There was a kid. Kids.

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE OFFICER
dialogues.text: Sure, hon- not do it again.

dialogues.speaker: BEARDED MAN
dialogues.text: Use houses or get busted?

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE OFFICER
dialogues.text: One would take care of the other, wouldn't it? Next time, you’1ll be processed. He nods. She returns to her sandwich.  11 12 13 14 FEMALE OFFICER (CONT’D) And I‘’d worry more about the realtor. Those places go for three thousand a week. (bites, chews) Four.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Bearded Man stands curbside, gazing vulnerably into RUSHING TRAFFIC.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LOOKING TOWARDS THE OCEAN, a CROWDED stretch of beach. The Bearded Man hunches into a foreground SILHOUETTE, settling under the shade of the boardwalk. Foot traffic CLUNKS above as he observes the bustle. A TOSSED FOOD CARTON lands in the nearby sand. He looks u SEAGULLS HOVER ABOVE, aggressively competing for scraps. THE SOUNDSCAPE FUSES INTO WHITE NOISE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE WIND WHIPS across the now desolate beach. An older couple scan the shore with a METAL DETECTOR. The Bearded Man collects RECYCLABLES, placing them in an oversized canvas bag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Bearded Man drags the bag through reeds and coarse gr He digs into his shirt collar and lifts a BALL BEARING NECKLACE over his head. Threaded through the necklace, a set of CAR KEYS. He unlocks the trunk of a BLUE FOUR-DOOR 1990 PONTIAC BONNEVILLE, in disrepair and weathered by the sun. He heaves the recyclables into the trunk and latches it.  15 16 17 18 19

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Bearded Man opens the driver’s side doors, throwing l onto stacks of neatly folded clothes, books and supplies. pillow and sheets line the back seat. He pulls out BOOTS and throws a SATCHEL over his shoulder FROM THE FRONT OF THE VEHICLE, chipped paint and rust surround BULLET HOLES grouped by the windshield frame.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FROZEN CUSTARD, AMUSEMENT RIDES and OVERFLOWING GARBAGE C The beachfront shops cash-in on an ARMY OF TOURISTS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The BOARDWALK DIN carries to a hotel service entrance. Th Bearded Man expertly sifts through a DUMPSTER. He wipes grease off a ‘FUNLAND’ TICKET BOOK and tucks it away. He rescues a FATTY CUT OF MEAT from a nest of foil. Openi his satchel, he reveals a FOOD-PREP KIT WITH MISMATCHED COOKING UTENSILS AND CONTAINERS. He places the meat in Tupperware, adding a homemade marin before sealing the lid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON A TIN PLATE: STEAK BONES sucked clean. The Bearded Man wraps a RAG around the handle of a dented CAMPING KETTLE and pulls it from a COOKING FIRE. He pours BOILING WATER into a CUP.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WIND through reeds, crashing WAVES, and CHIRPING Crickets The Bearded Man reclines in the back, sipping tea and rea under a solar garden lamp hung from sagging upholstery. His eyes drift from the page. He slides the ‘FUNLAND’ TIC into the crease and closes the book. FROM OUTSIDE, the lamp dims to black.  20 21 22 23 24 25 26

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THROUGH A LONG LENS: Distorted by rising heat from the crowded boardwalk planks, the Bearded Man offers somethin his hand to several PASSERS-BY. He is ignored.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON THE ‘FUNLAND’ TICKETS: six are ripped from the book. A TICKET-TAKER seats the Bearded Man in a suspended track ride-car and secures the lap bar. The ride-car lurches forward and up through hydraulic HAU MANSION DOORS with a BLAST OF PIPE ORGAN MUSIC...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Bearded Man RUMBLES PAST A MIRROR MAZE, BOBBING SKULL HOWLING WEREWOLVES, A MISTY GRAVEYARD... A STROBE flashes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE EXIT DOORS HISS OPEN: The Bearded Man squirms from th ride-car before the ATTENDANT can lift the lap bar. A GHOULISH LAUGH through crackling speakers. EXT. ‘WHAC-A-MOLE’ BOOTH - FUNLAND - AFTERNOON 24 The Bearded Man SLAPS the ticket book on the counter of a WHAC-A-MOLE amusement game. A LUCKY KID snatches it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Bearded Man CASTS A ROD AND REEL from the surf, his SATCHEL over his shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By the light of a MAKESHIFT HEAD-LAMP, the Bearded Man FILLETS A BLUEFISH with a CORK HANDLED FISHING KNIFE.  27 28 29 30

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ‘O-Dark-thirty’. A COMPACT CAR drifts by upscale homes, tossing out NEWSPAPERS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cast in deep blue light diffused through dew-covered wind the Bearded man lies curled in the back seat. TIRES CREEPING ACROSS SANDY ASPHALT. THROUGH THE DRIVER'S SIDE WINDOW, abstracted by moisture, POLICE LIGHTS roll in. A CAR DOOR opens and shuts. A BLUR FIGURE approaches the Bonneville and KNOCKS. The Bearded Man rises, waiting with blinking eyes.

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: It's officer Eddy. He flips the lock and pushes the door open for OFFICER ED the Female Officer from the police station.

dialogues.speaker: OFFICER EDDY
dialogues.text: I'd like you to come in to the station.

dialogues.speaker: BEARDED MAN
dialogues.text: Is this about the house? I coul-

dialogues.speaker: OFFICER EDDY
dialogues.text: Dwight, sweetheart, I’1l explain. Just come with me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Bearded Man, DWIGHT, stews in the back of the cruiser FLASHING THE CRUISER’S TURRET, Officer Eddy coasts throug red light and turns off the road.

dialogues.speaker: OFFICER EDDY
dialogues.text: How ‘bout some breakfast?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cruiser rolls under a canopy up to a DRIVE-THRU WINDO The SPEAKER CRACKLES.  31 32

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A SKELETON CREW works to the HUM of vending machines and few SLURRED OUTBURSTS from the drunk tank. Officer Eddy guides Dwight past empty desks and down a hallway, carrying a TAKE-OUT BAG and NEWSPAPER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Officer Eddy seats Dwight at a kitchenette table and pull boxed food from the bag.

dialogues.speaker: OFFICER EDDY
dialogues.text: I apologize for the mystery- I don’t mean to scare you. You’re not in any trouble, everything’s fine- She winces into a solemn, regretful grin. Dwight settles his seat as she takes hers.

dialogues.speaker: OFFICER EDDY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: -you'll be fine. Oh, see, I just don’t know exactly how to handle this. And I know I’m not to bring this up- but, honey, someone brought this to our stoop. (unfolding the newspaper) I just thought you should be somewhere safe when you found out. Dwight suppresses a rush of realization.

dialogues.speaker: OFFICER EDDY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: With somebody... She slides the newspaper across the table. He pulls it cl without laying eyes on it. His attention shifts to a WALL CALENDAR hanging behind her.

dialogues.speaker: OFFICER EDDY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He’s going to be released. I’m not sure how much you... I just need you to know that you’re safe and that you can let me know whatever you need. They are missed. It’s an awful thing he did to them. I’m just going to hold you here for a little bit, let you breathe And who knows? This might even be an opportunity... HER VOICE WASHES INTO CARDIOVASCULAR PULSING. DWIGHT’S FACE GOES SLACK.  33 34 35 36 37 38 10.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dwight takes the center of a residential street, moving numbly through pools of orange light, the NEWSPAPER in ha COLLEGE KIDS watch him from a outdoor hot tub. Their mout are moving, but Dwight hears no voices.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dwight takes a solitary swim in the Atlantic. And goes under for a long time... EXT. SUPERMARKET —- MORNING 35 Aluminum and glass CLANK into a self-serve RECYCLING MACH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dwight hands a RECEIPT to a CASHIER and sets a ‘DE, MD, V ROAD MAP on the counter. He looks half-dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dwight pops the lid off a rusted coffee can from his trun He adds a handful of SMALL BILLS to the modest stash. He pulls out a GAS CANISTER and sets it down. ..-opens the driver's side door, pops the gas and the hoo .-.-Shakes the canister, empties it into the tank. ..-walks an 8” cube wrapped in plastic bags from the trun the hood. .»»-peels away the plastic bags, revealing a CAR BATTERY. .+-props the hood open, sets the battery in the tray and secures the connections.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dwight places the map on the seat and turns the engine ov Beside the map is THE NEWSPAPER. An article is titled: ‘9 PLEA DEAL MANDATES VA DOUBLE MURDERER FREED.  39 40 4l 42 11.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HALF-FLAT FRONT TIRES roll back, breaking free of overgro grass. The car reverses out of the sandy lot onto the str

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A general store with a fueling station. Dwight presses a HISSING AIR HOSE to a tire, behind him a display of color rafts and floatation devices. He moves to the next tire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HAND GUNS LAID ON VELVET, behind thick glass. TAGS tied t the trigger guards are marked from $180-$700. Dwight thumbs his cash and pockets it, surveying the shop florescent lights, drop ceiling and linoleum. He drifts a the gun displays, spotting HIMSELF ON A SURVEILLANCE MONI atop a stack of VHS DECKS. He locates the security camera turns to the WOMAN behind the register. She glances under the counter and stares back hard. Dwight approaches. She steps closer to the counter. He stops at the register and spins a CAROUSEL OF POSTCARD

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: Do you sell stamps?

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: I do. But those ones have postage included.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE-UP, POSTCARD: OUT OF FOCUS TEXT, a BALLPOINT PEN ho above in contemplation... In crude script: ‘Your brother,’

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Bonneville idles beside a MAILBOX. Dwight signs his n and deposits the postcard.  43 44 45 12.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dwight drives a two lane highway bordered by corn fields metal framed irrigation equipment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CICADAS drown out THUMPING LIVE MUSIC. Dwight watches HEADLIGHTS SWEEP BY before exiting the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A jumbo shack-themed bar for half-assed bikers. Dim light from the facade casts a warm edge onto the VEHICLES in th lot. Dwight walks along the cars, inspecting their conten He tries a car door- LOCKED. He tries the next- UNLOCKED- and rummages inside, thrown by the OVERHEAD INTERIOR LIGHT. Nothing. Another UNLOCKED DOOR. He SWITCHES OFF the interior light before searching. Nothing again. Cupping glass, Dwight checks the cab of a locked PICKUP TRUCK. He moves to ANOTHER TRUCK a few spots down with a ‘NATIONAL ASSOCIATION OF RIFLE OWNERS’ WINDOW DECAL. He spies something on the cab’s floor, angling his head f better view. He circles around and tries the other door- LOCKED... AND A LOUD FUCKING ALARM. Dwight flees, nearly tripping over a ROCK- he snatches it does an about face and SMASHES it through the cab window. He reaches through the jagged glass and unlatches the doo pulling a SMALL PLASTIC CASE from under the seat. THE LIVE MUSIC SURGES as a COWBOY exits the bar holding a CUP, wresting his keys from his tight jeans. Dwight dives behind his car, panicking across the dirt. The COWBOY aims his keys at the BLARING truck. TWO QUICK HONKS and the ALARM IS SILENCED. The Cowboy hea back inside with a BELCH.  46 47 48 49 50 51 13.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dwight rolls up his window. DUST SETTLES as he checks the rear view and opens the case beside him: BINGO- A SNUB-NO REVOLVER fitted in foam with SIX .357 CARTRIDGES. He lifts the weapon, noticing a HEAVY DUTY TRIGGER LOCK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MUTED, RHYTHMIC CRACKING ECHOES through the river valley. The Bonneville is parked alone in the lot, below tall tre and rock formations. WATER RUSHES nearby. There’s a small PLAQUE for tourists, a rustic TRASH BIN and PORTA-POTTIES

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dwight SMASHES THE REVOLVER’S TRIGGER LOCK WITH A TIRE IR He assesses the damage- very little. He places the gun on rock and pounds with more and more might and less and les control, following it with wild swings into the dirt. THWAP, THWAP, CRUNK. The metal gives. He dusts off the gu it’s broken in several places, the TRIGGER LOCK STILL INT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TRACKING WITH DWIGHT, marching in disappointment towards trash bin. He watches a HYBRID SUV pull in with a half- hearted smile and nod. He discretely deposits the broken gun, returning to the Bonneville as the SUV DRIVER (40), fit and wearing fleece hops out with a LEASH and a LATTE. A DOG BARKS from the SUV as Dwight pulls out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Bonneville weaves between eastern foot-hills.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A shadowed ROAD SIGN against a waning blue sky. HEADLIGHTS illuminate it: ‘PRISON AREA: HITCHHIKING PROHIBITED’  52 53 54 55 56 57 14.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Soft morning light. Dwight sits with predatory stillness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Bonneville is parked a few rows from the lot’s edge w a view of the prison gate. Rising behind it is high fenci razor wire and concrete.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Midday sun beams into the car. The PATTER OF LIQUID FLOWING INTO PLASTIC. Dwight is hunc in his seat, eyes to his lap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LOW ANGLE OF TIRES AND GRAVEL, the prison visible between ground and the car chassis: the driver's side door opens urine pours from a plastic bottle onto the gravel. A large sedan pulls into the lot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dwight tugs his door closed, observing THROUGH THE

dialogues.speaker: WINDSHIELD
dialogues.text: An early ‘90s model WHITE STRETCH LIMOUSINE parks in the closest to the prison gates. ON THE DOOR: ‘CLELAND LIMOUS From the far side, A MAN and a WOMAN step out for cigaret the engine idling. Dwight half turns the keys in the ignition and rolls down passenger side window. Their VOICES compete with MUSIC emanating from the limous their smoke puffs drift into the wind. Dwight pulls his satchel from the floor and rests it on t passenger’s seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LOUDER MUSIC and LAUGHTER from behind the closed doors of limousine. Dwight’s Bonneville hasn’t moved.  58 59 60 15.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dwight squints at the prison entrance. An INMATE (42, whi male) is being escorted out by a CORRECTIONS OFFICER. The inmate struts in prison issued slacks and shirt, carrying cardboard BOX. He’s tattooed up his arms and neck, strong with a gut. Dwight is frozen. THE FAMILY exits the limousine with a brief BLAST OF MUSI The TEDDY (45), stocky in casual preppie attire, hops bac inside the driver’s seat to lower the volume. There’s CARL(39), wiry and tattooed in baggy clothes, CHR (46), scornful with teased, dirty blond hair, and HOPE (4 tight pony-tail and a dark, chiseled face. A BOY (14), lanky with hand-me-down clothes, scoots to th edge of the back seat, slouched over a HAND-HELD VIDEOGAM CONSOLE. The corrections officer hands the inmate a white envelope heads back with PARTING WORDS. The Family Members circle Inmate. Chris motions for the Boy to greet the Inmate, but he refuses. She power-walks over and grabs the Boy around th biceps. He shakes her off, retreating into the car as she palms his chin and shoves it back. They all pile back in the limousine. Dwight starts his car.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE REAR OF THE SPEEDING LIMOUSINE, FROM THE HOOD OF T
dialogues.text: BONNEVILLE, several car lengths back. CHRIS rises from the SUNROOF with a PLASTIC CUP in hand. flinches as airborne debris blows into her eye, the cup g flying as she awkwardly ducks below.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cup CLACKS PAST Dwight’s vibrating car. He checks the speedometer. They're averaging 83 MPH.  61 62 63 64 65 16.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The limousine pulls into the dirt lot of a single story stucco bar. The only other vehicle is a TRUCK FOR SALE. The Bonneville whips past, maintaining course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Watching his rearview, Dwight slows to a stop on the shoulder. P.O.V. (DWIGHT): HOPE yanks up a metal entrance gate, a PADLOCK in her hand. The Family follows her into the bar. ON DWIGHT as he rolls out into a wide U-turn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dwight pulls the Bonneville up a grassy incline beside th limousine and cuts the engine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dwight has a look around the car cabin and UNZIPS the satchel. He slides SOMETHING into his pant pocket. He closes his eyes. Then yanks the keys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dwight steps from the Bonneville, looping his key chain around his neck and tucking it into his shirt. TRACKING WITH DWIGHT as he shuts the door and walks unsteadily around the side of the building. A SOUND SYSTEM inside the bar cycles through RADIO STATIO Muffled, celebratory VOICES lure Dwight towards the back. He tries a side door near a dumpster. Locked. A DOOR SPRING. A WOMAN'S VOICE. A CLINKING CHAIN. Dwight follows the wall towards the sound, peeking one ey beyond the edge of the building. Hope is crouched by the rear entrance, opening cellar doo as the Teddy rolls a BEER KEG from a gated cold-storage u  66 67 17. Dwight rotates out of sight, his back to the wall.

dialogues.speaker: OLDER TEDDY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Stop breathing out your mouth.

dialogues.speaker: HOPE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Yeah, if you stop talking out your ass. Putting him on your books- they’1l be looking at you if he fucks up even once- and it won’t be on me... Dwight TUNES OUT, drawn to a DISTANT RUMBLE above. IN THE SKY: a drifting contrail in the wake of a jet... The cellar doors swing SHUT. Dwight pivots around the corner- they’re gone. He slips inside the back door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From bright daylight into a black cave. AUTO-TUNED RAP SWELLS as Dwight navigates the memorabilia lined hallway, his eyes adjusting to the darkness. TRACKING BEHIND DWIGHT, as he reaches in his pocket and p out the CORK HANDLED FISHING KNIFE. He passes the kitchen, steadying himself against the wall nearly knocking off a framed picture. He presses his hand a door and it swings open...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It’s a cramped, dingy-tiled bathroom bisected by a narrow walkway. On one wall: two stalls and a trash can. On the other: two urinals and a stickered-up mirror mounted abov porcelain sink. Dwight crosses the walkway and turns to face the door. He adjusts the blade in his hand. The MUSIC lowers, then blasts LOUDER. ON DWIGHT, inching towards the door- VOICES from just bey it stop him short.  18. The Convict and Carl push through the door, drinking from plastic cups.

dialogues.speaker: CONVICT
dialogues.text: Naw, man- she just talks too much. Shit- I ain’t used to that.

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: She talks shit, or she just talks too much? IN THE FAR STALL, Dwight stands silent, shadowed.

dialogues.speaker: CONVICT
dialogues.text: (jokingly fed up) Motherfucker. The two men place their cups atop the urinals and relieve themselves.

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: What, me too?

dialogues.speaker: CONVICT
dialogues.text: Yeah, maybe just let me piss. Haven’t done it alone with four walls in over a decade.

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: Ha, dude. They share a bit of a laugh then urinate in silence. Carl Finishes up and ZIPS. CARL (CONT’D) Hey, man. You all right?

dialogues.speaker: CONVICT
dialogues.text: Got some shit lined up. Favors. Carl walks to the door. CONVICT (CONT’D) You ain’t gonna wash up?

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: Naw, man, I don’t piss on my hands. (walking out) You want another one? Or you want beer?

dialogues.speaker: CONVICT
dialogues.text: All that shit...  19.

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: I hear that. The door swings shut behind Carl. The Convict lets out a deep breath, passes some gas. He zips up, his face expressionless as he steps to the si across from the far stall. Dwight is three feet from the Convict, DIRECTLY BEHIND HIM. The Convict pumps soap, scrubs his hands. INSIDE THE STALL, Dwight watches, sweaty, seething. ON THE FISHING KNIFE, Dwight nervously auditions hand gri ON DWIGHT’S contorting face. The MUSIC IS LOUD. The convict splashes his face and inspects his pores in t mirror- his jaw tenses as his EYES LOCK ON A REFLECTION I THE STALL BEHIND HIM. Counterbalanced by fear and rage, Dwight’s thrust is almo lethargic. The Convict whirls around as the stall door pu open- DWIGHT SWINGS THE FISHING KNIFE, CUTTING A DEEP SLI INTO THE BACK OF THE CONVICT’S NECK. The Convict fails to register the wound and rushes Dwight grabbing him by the throat with jailhouse power, forcing against the stall.

dialogues.speaker: THE FUCK
dialogues.text: IN THE MIRROR BEHIND THEM, we see the severity of the Convict’s wound, LIKE A BLOODY GILL, AS IT RAPIDLY OVERFL WITH DARK RED FLUID. Dwight gasps in the Convict’s two-handed clench, flailing WEAKLY JABBING THE KNIFE INTO THE CONVICTS RIBS. CONVICT (CONT’D) C'MON, LET’S...

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT RAISES THE FISHING KNIFE AND THRUSTS IT DOWNWARD I
dialogues.text: THE CONVICT’S SKULL. The Convict lets out an open-mouthed GRUNT, the KNIFE PLANTED IN THE TOP OF HIS HEAD. Enraged, with shock setting in, the Convict throws Dwight towards the still-running sink, then to the floor. They slip and flail, bathed in blood. Dwight takes a beat until the Convict BLEEDS OUT, clutching Dwight’s shirt.  20. Dwight pushes off with his feet, his SHIRT RIPPING as he disentangles from the Convict, who crumples to the floor, wheezing. He stares at Dwight, a hint of recognition. CONVICT (CONT’D) (quietly) Do I know you? Dwight stares back.

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: Yes. Dwight ramps into hyperventilation.

dialogues.speaker: YES.
dialogues.text: He leans over the Convict, YANKS THE KNIFE FROM HIS SKULL

dialogues.speaker: YES
dialogues.text: Unhinged, Dwight STABS THE CONVICT REPEATEDLY IN THE CHES Then collapses, completely spent. SOMEONE POUNDS ON THE DOOR.

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (muffled, through door) Hurry the fuck up, man! Party’s for you! Dwight crawls to the sink, puts a bloody hand on it and p himself to his feet.

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (projecting further away) WHAT? HELL NO! HE’S PROBABLY BEATIN’ OFF. Dwight heaves with pain, resigned. He tosses the knife towards the door.

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (through door) Told you we shoulda had a hooker waiting... Two playful SMACKS AGAINST THE DOOR. Dwight’s breathing regulates. Eyes on the door: JUST MUSI  68 69 70 71 21. He turns off the running faucet and retrieves the knife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TRACKING WITH DWIGHT, COVERED IN BLOOD, swaying into the hallway and heading out the way he came. Behind him, Teddy walks off, oblivious. The RADIO STATION runs an ADVERTISEMENT, the stereo CYCLE THROUGH STATIONS, casual VOICES and LAUGHTER fill the voi until it lands on CLASSIC ROCK. As Dwight exits, the sunlight is blinding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dwight treads heavily towards the Bonneville, past the limousine. He turns back and STABS THE LIMOUSINE’S FRONT TIRE, HIS HAND SLIDING DOWN THE BLADE ON IMPACT. He leaves the knife in the FIZZLING tire, HIS HAND DRIPPI BLOOD TOWARDS HIS CAR.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dwight takes his seat, admiring the DEEP CUT ACROSS HIS FINGERS. He reaches into his collar, feels around his nec NO KEYS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DWIGHT’S CAR KEYS ON THE BATHROOM FLOOR, the broken ball- bearing necklace threaded through. CLASSIC ROCK ECHOES.

dialogues.speaker: CARL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (muffled, through door) Let’s go, brother. Coming in... In the background, the door swings in and impacts the Convict’s body, sliding it a few inches on the wet tile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WHISTLING WIND and QUIET ROCK. ON THE STABBED TIRE, as Dwight shuffles past. He rounds the limousine hood and tries the driver’s side UNLOCKED.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dwight sits and scours for keys- the ignition...the visor digs in a console CUP-HOLDER and pulls out a set, turning them in the ignition as the bar door opens. LOUD, OFFENSIVE MUSIC emanates from the limousine’s stere Dwight shifts and hits the gas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON THE STABBED TIRE, as it WHIRLS THE KNIFE. The limousine carves a wobbly path, kicking up DUST as th Family Members exit, confused, furious, bloody. Hope hold PUMP SHOTGUN. Chris and Carl sprint after the limousine, shouting hysterically.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dwight’s face quivers with emotion, but he can’t quite cr DOWN THE ROAD, about a quarter mile, there’s a CONCRETE BARRIER along a curve. MUSIC STILL BLASTS. ON THE SPEEDOMETER: from 50MPH to 70MPH.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The shredded tire DISINTEGRATES, only the rim remains, SHRIEKING METAL and SHOWERING SPARKS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dwight TURNS OFF THE BLASTING RADIO. Relaxing now, with peace soon upon him, he maxes out the speed of the teetering sedan. HE CLOSES HIS EYES.  78 79 80 23. In the relative quiet, A STEADY THUMPING IS NOW AUDIBLE. Dwight blinks aware, triangulating the source- it’s behin him, in the passenger compartment.

dialogues.speaker: VISIBLE BEHIND THE PASS-THROUGH WINDOW
dialogues.text: AGAINST THE SOUNDPROOF GLASS, unnerved but composed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The limousine WHIRS to a stop amidst SMOKE AND DUST. Dwight exits the car, caked in blood, opening the rear-hi passenger door like a zombie chauffeur. The BOY climbs out grasping his video game console, scurr a safe distance before turning to face Dwight. They regard each other. Chris and Carl pant towards them, far in the distance. Dwight pushes the passenger door closed and turns away.

dialogues.speaker: BOY
dialogues.text: Did you hurt Wade? Dwight turns back, breaths some air.

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: I did. Wade hurt my parents.

dialogues.speaker: BOY
dialogues.text: No he didn’t. He just helped out. The boy turns and walks the highway towards his relatives their frantic YELLING LOST IN THE WIND.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The limousine SPARKS past the barrier at sublethal speed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dwight hangs in limbo, his adrenaline dumped.

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: (under his breath) Silly...  81 82 83 84 85 24.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FROM INSIDE THE BONNEVILLE, Family Members congregate aro Dwight’s vehicle. The MAP and the NEWSPAPER flap on the passenger’s seat. LOST IN THE BACKGROUND: Chris YELLS ABUSIVELY at the Boy. Carl burns testosterone with VOWS OF REVENGE. Closer to the Bonneville, inspecting the bullet holes...

dialogues.speaker: HOPE
dialogues.text: Was that the car?

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY
dialogues.text: Yep.

dialogues.speaker: HOPE
dialogues.text: You think he was alone?

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY
dialogues.text: Do we care?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The limousine CARVES INTO A DITCH AND LANDS HARD. Dwight pops from the door, dismounts the SMOULDERING seda and walks off towards a TREE LINE on the far side of an o field.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dwight takes cover in the shade of trees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dwight DRY HEAVES, nestled between limbs of a fallen oak.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A shallow creek of mostly mud. Dwight follows the trickle water upstream to a CONCRETE DRAINAGE DITCH. He follows the ditch to a clearing, beyond which lies a RESIDENTIAL DEVELOPMENT.  86 87 88 89 90 91 25.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A crowded cul-de-sac of McMansions surrounded by vacant l Some homes are unfinished- cars in some driveways, piles red, upturned dirt in others.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dwight watches from closer in, crouched on a hill. All's quiet. A PILE OF BAGGED NEWSPAPERS lies two stoops

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A well kept, oversized home. Evening light filters throug the windows. A TV REMOTE with a shit-ton of buttons. Behind it, a FLAT SCREEN illuminates the room. A RIPPED-OPEN PACKAGE OF SANDWICH MEATS and an empty GALL JUG sit atop the kitchen counter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PUSHING TOWARDS the MASTER BATH as backlit STEAM drifts i the shadowed chamber.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The fogged-up medicine cabinet hangs open. A PLASTIC COMB RAZOR and SCISSORS sit between HIS AND HER SINKS littered with HAIR TRIMMINGS and pink, DILUTED BLOOD. IN THE SHOWER: Dwight scrubs the coagulated mess off his body, his face CLEAN SHAVEN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seated on the toilet, Dwight pours HYDROGEN PEROXIDE over GASHED HAND into a small trash bin. FIRST AID SUPPLIES ar laid out on the sink beside him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dwight picks through a rack of clothes, finding a modest outfit: COLLARED SHIRT, SLACKS AND WORK SHOES.  92 93 94 95 96 26. He finds a WORKOUT BAG on the floor and empties it of TEN GEAR, placing the contents neatly on a shelf.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dwight chugs water from the gallon jug. On the counter, the workout bag is zipped and loaded. Nex it, half a roll of paper towels and his bloody clothes in plastic grocery bag. Dwight refills the jug at the sink and chugs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dwight stands over the toilet pissing like a racehorse. INT. BATHROOM —- MCMANSION - LATER 94 Dwight combs his hair in the mirror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dwight cycles through LOCAL NEWS CHANNELS on the TELEVISI - CLICK - “A tornado touched down in Western VA" - CLICK “an area surgeon was accused of sexual abuse” - CLICK...

dialogues.speaker: NEWSCASTER, (ON TELEVISION)
dialogues.text: .«..porch. Small dogs and cats should be kept in an enclosure if left unattended, as coyotes are able to jump fences- get this Amy- up to seven feet, oops, it says ‘less than seven feet’- I guess that would make it six feet and eleven inches and anything below? Curious wording...

dialogues.speaker: CO-ANCHOR/AMY, (ON TELEVISION)
dialogues.text: (rescuing her co-anchor) - More or less Steven, and I was surprised that they could climb even taller...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dwight locks the door handle before closing it, the worko bag draped over his shoulder and the grocery bag in hand.  97 98 99 27.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dwight circles from the porch to a basement window left a He slides it shut and trots silently across the sodded la

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dwight stuffs the bag of soiled clothes into a pebbled tr receptacle near the perimeter of a truck stop. Industrial lights cast a sick hue across the asphalt lot. BIG RIGS all over- CHUGGING on and off the highway, linin for fuel, idling in an adjacent lot. Dwight heads for a filling station CONVENIENCE STORE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dwight clears the side of the store, stepping into the fluorescent lights of its facade and within yards of a pa STATE POLICE CRUISER. The STATE TROOPER is visible inside, paying for coffee. Dwight’s eyes track the Trooper as he exits the store and settles in to his cruiser. The Trooper throws Dwight a dismissive glance and starts the engine. Dwight steps closer with an awkward, expectant gaze. The Trooper backs out, reversing over to Dwight.

dialogues.speaker: STATE TROOPER
dialogues.text: (rolling down window) You alright, sir?

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: Are... you looking for me?

dialogues.speaker: STATE TROOPER
dialogues.text: (halfhearted jest) Not unless you’re looking for trouble... A forced smile from the trooper, nothing in return from Dwight... STATE TROOPER (CONT’D) Okay then. You got ID?  100 101 28. Dwight fishes in his pocket, pulls out a RUBBER-BAND WALL and hands over a ratty ID. The trooper runs his name. STATE TROOPER (CONT’D) You have a vehicle here, Mr. Evans? You driving?

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: Not right now, no.

dialogues.speaker: STATE TROOPER
dialogues.text: Good. This is a learner’s permit from... (inspecting the ID) ..-nineteen ninety-seven. You got anything else?

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: No, sir.

dialogues.speaker: STATE TROOPER
dialogues.text: Get this up to date. And I don’t want you hitchhiking in the meantime, alright?

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: STATE TROOPER
dialogues.text: Have a safe night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dwight stares out from the cab of a truck, the DRIVER foc on the road ahead. CRACKLING COUNTRY MUSIC and RUSHING WI

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two KIDS (4&6), watching TELEVISION. A DOOR BELL RINGS. A MOM (39) walks through, plucks CAR KEYS from a CERAMIC atop a cluttered table and exits into the foyer. A DOOR floods daylight inside and she reappears with a BA SITTER (30's).  102 103 104 105 29.

dialogues.speaker: MOM
dialogues.text: (to the sitter) Bit of a late start- you mind moving the sprinkler into the bushes in about twenty minutes?

dialogues.speaker: BABY SITTER
dialogues.text: Sure, yeah. The Mom kisses her kids on the cheeks.

dialogues.speaker: MOM
dialogues.text: Then turn it off after fifteen. They painted Shrinky-Dinks last night- if you could put ‘em in the oven? I think three minutes at three-fifty- it’s on the box.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Mom walks briskly from the modest, two-story home. A ‘FOR SALE’ SIGN is staked in the neat grass. Juggling her keys, purse and a file folder, she ducks beh a hedge and OPENS AN EXTERIOR FAUCET. INT. HATCHBACK —- RANCH HOUSE - MORNING (CONTINUOUS) 103 The Mom slips into the car as water PATTERS across the windshield. She starts up, plops her purse and checks the REAR VIEW MIRROR. She waits for the passing sprinkler and rolls down her window...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...She pops her head out towards the rear.

dialogues.speaker: MOM
dialogues.text: (friendly warning) Pulling out! Dwight, standing at the edge of her driveway, sidesteps t the lawn. The Mom retracts into the car with a wave. INT. HATCHBACK —- RANCH HOUSE - MORNING (CONTINUOUS) 105 PROFILE ON THE MOM as she backs the car out, struck by a REVELATION. She hits the brake.  106 107 30.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Mom pops her head back out with a furrowed brow.

dialogues.speaker: MOM
dialogues.text: Dwight?

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: Hi, Sam. The Mom, SAM, is quietly stunned. Dwight sets his bag down and cautiously approaches.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Dwight? He’s clean shaven, in respectable attire, his ill-fitting shirt tucked tight into his pants.

dialogues.speaker: SAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (searching) «.-You look good. His pained eyes, his BANDAGED AND BLOODY HAND.

dialogues.speaker: SAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (shifting car into ‘park’) Or do you? WIDE SHOT: Dwight backs away as Sam swings open the car d and stands. A protracted silence, then a tentative embrac ...the SPRINKLER TICKS ITS SPRAY onto them.

dialogues.speaker: SAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Let me call work. She has another look and Dwight, starts untucking his shi

dialogues.speaker: SAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: .+-sorry, but ‘no’ to this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An independent version of Roy Rogers half full with LOCAL At the register, Sam lifts a plastic tray, one shoulder bracing her phone. Dwight, seated, watches her approach. Two wrapped breakfa sandwiches slide in front of him atop the tray. Sam scoot into the booth across.  31.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Wish I had more time, I’ve got an asset inventory that can’t push. Dwight absorbs the surreal setting.

dialogues.speaker: SAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You need money?

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: No, I - did you get my letter?

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: There haven’t been any letters.

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: Sent it after I crossed the bridge- it was a postcard.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: No. When?

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: Couple of days ago.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Yeah, postcards take more time- Dwight, I’m not following...

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: I sent it on my way to Deerfield. She leans with deep concern.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: I know he’s out, if that’s why you're here. D.O.C. sends a notification. And a restraining order. Let’s not... She trails off, unwraps her sandwich.

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: You're selling the house?

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Have been. For two years. It’s not really a hot market here. I've gotten a better job since then... She bites into her sandwich. Not enjoyable.

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: But you want to leave?  32.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: The absolute second I can.

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: Why can’t you?

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Good god, Dwight. You want me to answer that?

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: Sorry. It’s fine... (stretching jaw) I’m not used to talking this much.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Well, it’s what people do.

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: I know. He unwraps his sandwich. It’s greasy and grey.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Do you? Wanna know what I do? Dwight kindly postures for a storm.

dialogues.speaker: SAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m a secretary for a probate attorney. Dwight can’t ask.

dialogues.speaker: SAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: They settle estates. I knew so much about it, he hired me during the interview... (fighting tears) I couldn't ‘just leave’. I fought Uncle Steve in court. He wanted the house. I got the IRS on him and he took off to the Philippines. I was holding on but there was nothing... (blowing a breath) So I married an asshole. He tried to take the house too. I probably should've let him... Dwight reaches for Sam’s hand. She pulls away, then takes hold of his.  33.

dialogues.speaker: SAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Crap. I took us here so this wouldn’t happen. There’s way too much...

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: I’m sorry I left.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: I'm sorry too. (sniffs, wipes) For this busted sandwich.

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: I’ve had worse. They behold their sandwiches.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: As far as the estate- you’re still owed twenty eight hundred dollars.

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: You keep it.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: I spent it on new siding for the house. It apparently needed curb appeal. I'll pay you from the proceeds when it sells- if it sells. And there’s still a box of your things. I gave some to the kids- mostly the toys. Sold the rest at yard sales.

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: It’s fine. Keep it all.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Dwight, I don’t want it. And you need to register the Bonneville in your name if you still have it. I have spare keys if you want ‘em.

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: It's...gone. They share some silence.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: So, how’s Delaware?

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: You knew...?  34.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Not exactly where. We still go when we can- every few years, keep the tradition. Mostly for the kids- I've got two now.

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: I know-I mean... I saw you. Few summers ago.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: You didn’t say anything?

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: I... looked a mess. His hand retracts and presses his sandwich bun.

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You were on the boardwalk. Your older one was crying.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: So why now? Wade Cleland gets released?

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: I thought it’d be on the news, but there’s nothing...

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: We knew. This was the deal to avoid trial. Dwight wraps his sandwich then stops.

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: (whispering) I killed him, Sam. I killed Wade Cleland. She looks again at his bandaged hands, mild shock setting

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: What? Bullshit. When?

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: I think yesterday...

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: God damn you. This was over.

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: Never for me.  35.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: People don’t do this. Dwight shrugs a pathetic laugh.

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: Thought he’d kill me first.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Well I’m glad he didn’t. (quiet, seething) And I’m glad he’s dead. I hope he suffered... Sam's attention is drawn to a LARGE MAN looking straight them, sitting behind Dwight at an adjacent booth.

dialogues.speaker: LARGE MAN
dialogues.text: S‘’cuse me. Dwight turns to face him. LARGE MAN (CONT’D) Y'all got ketchup on yours? We don’t. Sam slides their KETCHUP to Dwight, who passes it over hi shoulder to the Large Man. LARGE MAN (CONT’D) Sorry, thank you. Dwight and Sam stare at each other.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: The Clelands still live up on East Hundred. The older one, he owns limousines-

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: (between her words) Yup.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: -How great is that? Operates out of Charlottesville. Every time I see one on the way to the airport, or pass through town- fucking June, fucking prom... You don’t own-

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Home. With the sitter...

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: (standing up) Let’s get back in your car.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: (following) What? Why?

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: They never called the police.

dialogues.speaker: MUSIC FADES-IN
dialogues.text: Dwight takes the wheel. Sam takes shotgun, dialing her ph HAND HELD, CHOPPY CUTS. TIME IS BROKEN. THE ROAD BLURS THROUGH THE WINDSHIELD.

dialogues.speaker: SAM, (BARELY AUDIBLE)
dialogues.text: She's not picking up. She’s not picking up!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PUSHING TOWARDS THE HOUSE, THE PIERCING STRINGS CUT OUT a the hatchback SCRAPES up the driveway and SKIDS to a halt Dwight and Sam race from the car.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: No no no no no no... Dwight makes it to the door.

dialogues.speaker: BABYSITTER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Wait! The Babysitter stands from behind the hedge, holding the sprinkler.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Oh my god. Sam runs past Dwight into the house, the Babysitter follo  112 37.

dialogues.speaker: BABYSITTER
dialogues.text: What’s wrong?!

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: Me...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Dwight enters, he’s SMACKED REPEATEDLY IN THE FACE by her kids in the background, SAFE AND SOUND. Dwight barely resists. The Sitter looks the children over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam pulls BURNT SHRINKY-DINKS from the oven, tossing them into a flip up GARBAGE CAN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dwight peers into the kitchen through a glass-pained door

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: (through door) ...She knew them from the beach. I think she knew dad from the car shows. We don’t talk much about it, but she looks out for me. I’1l do it there. Her name is... I forgot her first name. Officer Eddy. Sam appears through the glass, Dwight straightens up.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: (through door) The Clelands need to be arrested.

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: (rubbing his face) All of them? For what? Sam nervously bites her lip, leaves frame. Some CLANKING from the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (through door) I‘1l turn myself in here if that’s what you want. But I can’t do it until I know you’re safe- the kids are safe. Just go. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: If you want, call the police from Pittsburgh. As long as you're not here, Sam. Sam reappears, UNLATCHES the door and opens it a crack.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: It’s my house, Dwight.

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: They know it, and the car is registered here. It’s not worth- I messed up, sis... (fading) I didn’t mean to scare you.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Well, I’m scared.

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: Is there a gun in the house?

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Of course not. She walks off, leaving the door open. Dwight enters and locks the door behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The television sits on the floor, an extension cord attac Sam's two kids are seated on the floor, watching it. Dwight sits by the closed door, watching the children.

dialogues.speaker: SAM, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (muffled, through door) Okay. I only told work. Nobody else. He opens the door, Sam stands amongst hastily PACKED BAGS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dwight closes the packed trunk. He walks to Sam’s window she puts the car in gear.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: I'd forgive you if you were crazy. But you’re not. You’re weak.  120 39. She backs out of the driveway. Dwight watches them leave. The car stops, then keeps goin

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The air conditioner is dialed off, silencing a rickety HU The front window is cracked open, EXTERIOR SOUNDS pour in A lamp is turned off. Then another. A kitchen drawer is opened. Dwight removes a FLASHLIGHT. A LETTER OPENER too. Winter coats, a scooter, umbrellas... a closet door SHUTS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A rusty shed door SQUEALS open. Dwight selects a broom- handled, metal-spiked WEEDER from a RACK OF TOOLS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Street light spills in, silhouetting Dwight by the window Just CRICKETS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dwight scans the backyard through the kitchen door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dwight dozes in the chair, his chin sunk into his neck. H sucks in air, groggily uprighting himself. OUT THE WINDOW: still clear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dwight prepares a cup of tea by flashlight, careful to pu the kettle off the burner just before it whistles.  121 122 123 124 40.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The flashlight beam pushes through the door and sweeps lo settling on an ATTIC DOOR in the wall. Dwight unlatches it and pulls, inspecting faded PENCIL SCRAWLINGS that once transformed the inside panel into a spaceship cockpit. He crawls into the dark and drags out a CARDBOARD BOX. He pulls out a shoebox, paper stacks and a dusty yearbook bound in blue leather. Leafing through the pages, he- THE HUM OF AN ENGINE echoes quietly through the house. He sets the yearbook down and kills the flashlight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dwight descends the stairs, old wood CREAKING underfoot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dwight floats to the window, LOOKING OUT:

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: Shit. There’s SHAPES within the car, hard to make out. ON THE BONNEVILLE: A FLICKER WARMS CARL’S FACE as he ligh smoke, its ember lingering in the dark. ON DWIGHT: Reaching for the garden weeder propped against wall: IT SLIPS FROM HIS GRASP, SCRAPES THE WALL AND CLUNK THE FLOOR. He grimaces, frozen with anticipation... ON THE BONNEVILLE: The ember is snatched and tossed out b the driver’s silhouette, ORANGE SPARKS bounce from the cu

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dwight grabs the weeder, crossing the foyer into the adja dining room. He settles by a window closer in and waits.  125 126 127 128 129 130 41. No movement from the car. His eyelids grow heavy. AMBIENT SOUND BUILDS TO A STING.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dwight opens his eyes. BACK TO CRICKETS. ON THE BONNEVILLE: NOW TWO GLOWING EMBERS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dwight sets the weeder down and CREAKS his way upstairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keeping low, Dwight grabs bed pillows and positions them under the sheets to emulate a person. He crawls to a beds table and reaches up into a lamp shade...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FROM OUTSIDE, the bedroom window WARMS WITH LIGHT, now a beacon in the dark.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dwight crawls into the bathroom, craning to FLICK ON THE LIGHT. He twists the SINK FAUCET ON. Backing out, he sets door open a crack.

dialogues.speaker: AN EMPTY DOOR FRAME. CREAK, CREAK, CREAK...
dialogues.text: Dwight slinks in and takes position by the window.

dialogues.speaker: THROUGH THE WINDOW
dialogues.text: The front door handle CLICKS. A TUG tests the lock. Dwight’s eyes dart around. He walks to the foyer, listeni winding up the garden weeder... The CLINK of a fence latch from the side of the house.  131 42. He double backs to the dining room, hugging the wall to a side window... THROUGH THE WINDOW: A fenced, narrow side yard filled wit junk, shadowed by the BLUE LIGHT OF A BUG-ZAPPER. Teddy moves through shadows with a SPORTING SHOTGUN. Dwight can hear his own pulse. He backs into the foyer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dwight peers through the living room into the kitchen:

dialogues.speaker: FUCK.
dialogues.text: Dwight heads to the front door, slowing his pace to appea THE SQUEAKING FLOOR. FROM THE KITCHEN, A MUFFLED POP, SPRINKLING GLASS... He squats to the door, surgically unlatching the lock. CL FROM THE KITCHEN, A few more TAPS, CLINKING GLASS... He turns the knob, cracks the front door, revealing a DIR VIEW OF THE BONNEVILLE. BZZZZ2Z. Just outside, a CELL PHONE LIGHTS UP with a text message. Carl removes a glove and types a response. Dwigh pulls back and re-locks the door. He commando-crawls to the living room, checking the kitch AT THE BACK DOOR, THROUGH BROKEN GLASS: Teddy’s face GLOW the cool light of his cell phone. Dwight crawls to the SIDE TABLE... He POPS ON HIS FLASHLIGHT, cupping the beam with his hand searching frantically through the CERAMIC JARS. THE BACK DOOR OPENS, FOOTSTEPS OVER GLASS AND LINOLEUM. Dwight sifts through rusty paperclips, rubber bands and coins, inspecting KEY SETS with plastic tabs and handwrit labels: ‘Honda’, ‘Shed’, ‘Ginny’.  132 133 134 43. He pulls a moldy set from the bottom of a jar: ‘PONTIAC’. THE FOOTSTEPS APPROACH. Dwight pockets his flashlight and makes a fist over the k crawling off as Teddy steps in. Dwight hides under the dining table, a bit exposed, containing his breaths. Teddy enters the foyer- shotgun first, stopping feet from Dwight. He unlocks the front door and opens it, greeting with his gloved index finger over his lips, gesturing upstairs:

dialogues.speaker: FROM WITHIN.
dialogues.text: Carl steps into Dwight’s view, nodding: he’s carrying a SCOPED HUNTING CROSSBOW, a sheathed BOWIE KNIFE hanging f his belt. The brothers ascend the SQUEAKY STAIRS with heavy boots. Behind them, Dwight crawls across the foyer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dwight steps through the kitchen, CRUNCHING over shards o glass and slipping out the back door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dwight breaks for the front fence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dwight pushes through the gate and scurries across the la SQUEAKING FROM THE HOUSE- Dwight looks back over his shoulder... ON THE FRONT BEDROOM WINDOW: Carl holding his crossbow upright, violently cranking the casement window open... DWIGHT SPRINTS TO THE BONNEVILLE. THMMMP- An ARROW rips through the air and CLANKS into the street. Dwight reaches the Bonneville and unlocks the doo with trembling hands.  135 136 137 138 139 140
Teddy jogs from the front door, heading straight towards Dwight with the shotgun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dwight starts the car and pops it into gear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Teddy slows and levels the shotgun. THMMMP. An ARROW WHIPS PAST Teddy, SINKING INTO A NEARBY TREE. He looks furiously up to Carl at the window. THE ENGINE REVS AND THE TIRES SCRUB PAVEMENT. INT. BONNEVILLE - SAM’S STREET - NIGHT (CONTINUOUS) 137 FLOORING IT, Dwight bites his lip and shuts his eyes. KAD EXT. SAM’S STREET - NIGHT (CONTINUOUS) 138 Teddy BOUNCES HARD OFF THE HOOD INTO THE STREET, the shot RATTLING beside him. He’s out cold. The Bonneville jolts to a stop. Dwight hesitates, then bu out and drags Teddy towards the idling car. Teddy exits the house, lining up a crossbow arrow. Dwight drops Teddy and scrambles for the shotgun. THMMMP. AN ARROW PINGS OFF THE HOOD OF THE CAR. Dwight snatches up the shotgun, hands inexpertly finding trigger and pump, sending Carl into full retreat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carl bolts up the driveway and through the wooden gate, Dwight giving chase with the shotgun...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dwight steps through the gate and stops cold. He can’t se into the BLUE DARKNESS and it’s suddenly DEAD QUIET. Nearby, A BUG GETS ZAPPED.  141 142 143 45. He huffs through an open mouth, calculating the risk... AND DARTS BACK TOWARD THE CAR.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dwight sets the shotgun next to Teddy and muscles him int the back. He slams the door and turns for the shotgun- THMMP. AN ARROW EMBEDS INTO DWIGHT’S HIP. Nearly collapsi he limps back, LEAVING THE GUN. Carl loads another arrow from Sam’s driveway. Dwight hops in the Bonneville and shifts, GRUNTING IN PAI THMMP, THE ARROW CRACKS THE FAR WINDOW. Carl drops the crossbow and sprints to the car, opening t back door as Dwight PEELS OUT. CARL IS YANKED TO THE STREET as Dwight speeds off with an open door. INT. BONNEVILLE (MOVING) - SAM’S STREET - NIGHT 142 Dwight steers, contorting to keep pressure off the ARROW HIS HIP. THROUGH THE BACK WINDOW: Carl gathers strewn weapons in t street... The car slows, then speeds up, SWINGING THE BAC DOOR SHUT. DAY IS STARTING TO BREAK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Teddy is unconscious across the back seat, WHEEZING throu his nose. Dwight searches his pockets, removing a WALLET, BLOODY CAR KEY NECKLACE, a CELL PHONE, a TOBACCO POUCH, SHOTGUN SHELLS and a FOLDED PAPER. He pockets CASH from the wallet and unfolds the paper. ON THE PAPER: THE BONNEVILLE’S EXPIRED VIRGINIA REGISTRAT listing the owners: ‘Evans, William C., Evans, Katherine He puts the loot in the glove box and POPS THE TRUNK. ON A WIDE: The car is parked in a desolate field under a purple-gray sky. The trunk bobs open.  144 145 146 46.

dialogues.speaker: THE ARROW PROTRUDING FROM HIS HIP, DWIGHT DRAGS TEDDY INT
dialogues.text: THE TRUNK, slamming it down and testing the latch. Reconsidering, HE POPS THE TRUNK AGAIN. CLOSEUP: TOOLS FROM THE TRUNK CLANK TO THE GROUND. He strips off Teddy’s hunting jacket, SLAMS THE TRUNK. He picks a HANDSAW from the grass and positions his hip against the open frame of his car door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MUZAK. Dwight hobbles down an isle with a basket, conceal his wound with Teddy’s jacket. ‘PAIN RELIEF’: He tips an ASPIRIN BOTTLE into his basket. ‘FIRST AID’: Grabs RUBBING ALCOHOL, PEROXIDE, GAUZE... ‘HOUSEHOLD’: A SEWING KIT, X-ACTO-KNIFE... ‘HARDWARE’: Sets down SEWING KIT, picks up SUPER-GLUE...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A CLERK counts behind a register, noticing BLOODY BILLS. He looks to Dwight. Dwight: So. Fucking. Tired.

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: Just uh... (walking away) Yup.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dwight is prepped in the back with a NOVICE SURGICAL KIT. pours HYDROGEN PEROXIDE on his wound. He dips NEEDLE-NOSE PLIERS in RUBBING ALCOHOL and goes to work. ON HIS GORY WOUND: Fatty tissue hugging the carbon shaft, tip buried within. The pliers delicately clamp down on th shaft. Then a tug. DWIGHT SCREAMS...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SLIDING AUTOMATIC DOORS PART FOR DWIGHT. He strides in, p and damp with sweat. A TRIAGE NURSE looks up from her computer.

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: (depleted) ‘Scuse me. I have a question. Maybe a little goofy...

dialogues.speaker: TRIAGE NURSE
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: Do you need- are you required- to report arrow wounds? Like an accident- hunting accident. With buddies. Alone, actually...

dialogues.speaker: TRIAGE NURSE
dialogues.text: Sir, do you need medical assistance?

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: Just, um...yeah. A little hunting accident- my hip. Do you need to report it, if it’s self-inflicted ..-by mistake?

dialogues.speaker: TRIAGE NURSE
dialogues.text: I'd have to check with the charge nurse, sir. I’ve never handled- DWIGHT COLLAPSES TO THE LINOLEUM.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dwight’s eyes flutter open. They close again in feigned sleep as a NURSE steps close, checking his CHART. He waits for her to walk off then lifts his gown to inspe THE WOUND: IT’S PROPERLY STITCHED AND DRESSED. There’s a wall mounted light box with an X-RAY OF HIS INJ There’s a bin of BLOODY POST-OP CLOTHES. He pulls TAPE and TUBING and NEEDLES from his arms.  149 150 151 152 48.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dwight climbs out a window wearing his bloody clothing, n HANGING FLAPS OF SURGICALLY CUT FABRIC.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MOVING WITH DWIGHT, as he walks under a secluded railroad bridge, cautiously approaching... ..-THE BONNEVILLE: PUSHING IN ON THE TRUNK. Dwight leans in, his ear to the trunk. He TAPS LIGHTLY-

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (muffled, in trunk) ..-HEY! I’M IN HERE! I GOTTA GET OUT! HELP... Dwight backs off and plucks the car keys from the wheel w

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dwight starts the engine, letting it idle as the PLEADING devolves to POUNDING HOSTILITY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dwight exits, walks over and SLAMS his fist on the trunk.

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: (projecting through steel) You're alone. You came into my sister’s house with guns. Unless you be quiet, I WILL DRIVE THIS

dialogues.speaker: DAMNED CAR OFF A BRIDGE
dialogues.text: The pounding and yelling stop. Dwight walks off... ON A PROFILE SHOT OF THE TRUNK (MOUNTED TO THE CAR). Dwight returns, bending down into frame.

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I just want this to be over.  153 154 155 156 49.

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (muffled, through trunk)

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: You guys got guns. I’m not opening the trunk until I have one.

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY
dialogues.text: Shit, I could get-

dialogues.speaker: BE QUIET.
dialogues.text: Dwight exits frame: HOLD ON TRUNK SHOT...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JUMP CUT OF THE SAME TRUNK SHOT, in a parking lot donatio site. Dwight sorts through MATTRESSES and JUNK, expertly digging out a BAG OF CLOTHES...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JUMP CUT OF THE SAME TRUNK SHOT, at a gas station. Dwight fills the tank, wearing a SWEATSHIRT AND CORDUROYS...

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: EXT. COMMERCIAL STRIP —- EVENING (CAR MOUNT) 155 JUMP CUT OF THE SAME TRUNK SHOT, stopping at a busy intersection...

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: EXT. SAM’S STREET - EVENING (CAR MOUNT) 156 JUMP CUT OF THE SAME TRUNK SHOT, turning off a tranquil street into SAM'S DRIVEWAY. THE CAR DOOR OPENS AND SHUTS SCREEN, Dwight speed walks into frame towards the house.  157 158 159 160 161 162 163 50.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A WIDE PROFILE OF THE STAIRCASE. A faint RUSH.. Dwight treads heavily through the door and up the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON THE SINK, THE WATER STILL RUNNING. Dwight turns the fa off, hits the lights and heads downstairs. Halfway down, he doubles back...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dwight’s CARDBOARD BOX, where he left it. He drags it off

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dwight places the box in the garbage, salvaging the YEARB He folds up a cardboard top-flap and RIPS IT OFF.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dwight TAPES THE CARDBOARD FLAP OVER THE BROKEN WINDOW. He sweeps up GLASS with a BROOM and DUSTPAN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON THE FRONT DOOR: Dwight swings it open and exits. It LOCKS from outside. HE DROPS THE HOUSE KEYS THROUGH THE MAIL SLOT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dwight flips though his YEARBOOK, circa 1996: TEENAGE PORTRAITS, names in black type: denim, Hard Rock Cafe’ shirts, acne, crimped hair and braces. BZZ2ZZZ2Z. A vibration inside the car. Dwight opens the g compartment and removes Teddy’s CELL PHONE. ON THE SCREEN: ‘C IS BACK. WHERE R U?!’  164 51.

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (muffled, through trunk) WHAT’S THAT? I NEED WATER.

dialogues.speaker: NOT UNTIL I HAVE A GUN.
dialogues.text: Dwight sets the phone down and returns to the yearbook. ON THE YEARBOOK: UNDER THE HEADING ‘JROTC’, A PORTRAIT OF TEENAGER IN MILITARY FATIGUES. TYPED UNDERNEATH: ‘BENJAMIN GALICIA’ EXT. BEN’S MOTHER'S HOUSE - NIGHT 164 An interior door opens inward, MARGARET GALICIA (67) stan guardedly behind a screen door.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: Hi, Mrs. Galicia. I’m looking for Ben. Is he still in town?

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: No, he moved a while ago.

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: Okay. I’m Dwight, from Orange High. I just...

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: Oh! I’m so sorry- you had me a little scared. Mr. Galicia is already in bed. I didn’t recognize you, Dwight. (a rush of sympathy) Oh my. Dwight deflects with a polite nod. MARGARET (CONT’D) Ben has a house near Wyndam. Come in, I'll write down the address... Margaret unlocks the screen door and Dwight follows her inside.  165 52. INT. KITCHEN - BEN’S MOTHERS HOUSE - NIGHT 165

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: He moved when he got back from Japan. He was deployed... Margaret leads Dwight to the kitchen table. She opens her address book on the counter, picks up a phone and dials.

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: Oh, he doesn’t know I’m coming-

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: (gesturing to sit) Oh he’1l be thrilled... He watches her as the line TONES. MARGARET (CONT’D) (hanging up) He’s not picking up. He works at a concert hall in the city. He's probably playing tonight...

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: Richmond?

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: Yes. I never remember the name. It’s not a nice place... She passes a finger along POST-ITS, MAGNETS and PHOTOS displayed on her refrigerator. She slides a BUSINESS CARD from under a magnet and brings her address book to the ta Dwight watches her pencil information onto the card and i her book. MARGARET (CONT’D) This way...we can both have everything...just need this...for myself... (pointing to the card) Here. This is where he works. (flipping it) This is where he lives. You can take this ‘to go’. A TEA KETTLE WHISTLES. She hands the card over and rises. MARGARET (CONT’D) You might need a map, it’s out of the way, off six twenty four.  166 167 168 53.

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: I’ve got a map. Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: Are you in a rush?

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: Sort of. Yes, ma'am.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: I'd offer you tea, otherwise. Dwight glances around, and at Margaret.

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: I'd love some, Mrs. Galicia.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: Oh good! Ben works late anyway. And they play God awful music... EXT. BEN’S MOTHERS HOUSE - NIGHT 166 THROUGH THE EXTERIOR WINDOW: Margaret pours Dwight tea in warm kitchen glow.

dialogues.speaker: POUNDING FROM THE TRUNK.
dialogues.text: Dwight speeds down the road, patting around his seat. He checks the glove box, shuts it. He reads the address off the business card, looks ahead.

dialogues.speaker: THROUGH THE WINDSHIELD
dialogues.text: A HIGHWAY SIGN: ‘Zion Crossroads, Fork Union Exit 136’ ANOTHER: ‘I64E Richmond’

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MUSIC BELLOWS WITHIN a textured concrete building with concert posters hung over blacked-out windows. Dwight walks up.  169 170 171 54.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dwight angles past SMOKERS, along a vinyl rope partition, greeted by a ROCK GIRL (20s).

dialogues.speaker: ROCK GIRL
dialogues.text: (over the music) FIVE DOLLARS. Disoriented by the THROBBING MUSIC, he pulls CRINKLED BIL from his pocket and hands them over. He continues past the Rock Girl as she counts six singles then yanks Dwight back.

dialogues.speaker: HOLD ON...
dialogues.text: Dwight resists as she steadies his arm, shoves the extra dollar in his hand and STAMPS IT with a BLACK-LIGHT LOGO. hurries off, inspecting it... ON HIS HAND IN GLOWING INK: ‘STRANGE MATTER’

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dwight dips through the crowd to the STAGE. He checks out BAND MEMBERS. NOTHING. He scans around, lost.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Rock Girl rolls her eyes as Dwight timidly approaches

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: EXCUSE ME. I’M LOOKING FOR A BAND MEMBER NAMED BEN. BEN GALICIA. HE’S

dialogues.speaker: ROCK GIRL
dialogues.text: HE’S HERE- HE WORKS THE BOARD. HE’S NOT IN THE BAND.

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: THAT’S FINE. WHEN DOES HE GO HOME?  172 55.

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: I’LL WAIT HERE.

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: (pivoting in search) OKAY. I’LL WAIT OUT AROUND BACK.

dialogues.speaker: ROCK GIRL
dialogues.text: (pointing) OUT THE FRONT AND AROUND THAT WAY. THERE’S AN ALLEY.

dialogues.speaker: THANK YOU. DO YOU THINK I COULD
dialogues.text: HAVE MY MONEY BACK? I COULDN’T STAY IN THERE...

dialogues.speaker: ROCK GIRL
dialogues.text: NO, MAN. YOU’RE GONNA NEED TO FUCK OFF...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: IT’S QUIET. A BAND is loading up GEAR into a CONVERSION V IN THE RED WASH OF BREAK LIGHTS, Dwight watches them pull out. He’s alone. There’s a DUMPSTER across the alley. He walks over, place his hand on the rim and rises onto tip-toes. He peeks in- A METAL DOOR SCREECHES OPEN. Dwight wipes his hands on hi shirt, observing a LARGE MAN with long black hair turn do the alley.

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: Ben? The Large Man walks on, insulated by HEAVY METAL MUSIC coursing through his HEADPHONES. Dwight follows.  173 174 56.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dwight steps from the alley, guided by HEADPHONE SPILL.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Large Man unlocks his PICKUP. Dwight stops short of t truck, noting the numerous MILITARY AND FIREARM DECALS.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: The Large Man turns, whipping his headphones off, LOUDER around his neck. Dwight stands ready with a cautious hand

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Ben. Hey, it’s Dwight. Evans. The Large Man, BEN, walks over, assessing the claim. Dwig meets him at the tailgate and they shake.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Wow, bro- you look square.

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: I’ve been away. Ben nods, waiting for more.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: No shit, man- just peaced-the-fuck- out... He pulls out cigarettes, Dwight declines and Ben lights u

dialogues.speaker: BEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: ...Same year El Duce got hit by a train. (slaps his truck) Yo, I put the first two hundred miles on this thing stapling up your ‘missing’ posters.

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: (struck, ashamed) Never thought of that.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Your sister, man. She was hell bent. Then I think a bunch of your parking tickets came in the mail- she called it all off...  57. Dwight nods, thrown off. They listen to HEADPHONE CRACKLE

dialogues.speaker: BEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I took off too! (lifting shirt, showing a ‘U.S.M.C.’ tattoo) Joined up soon as I graduated. Nev- Ben cuts himself off, cocking his head.

dialogues.speaker: BEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Was...that you? (pointing back) By the dumpster?

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Yeah... So should we get beers?

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: Look, I need to warn you that I’m here- that I came to you- for a favor. A big one. Ben reaches in his jacket, SILENCING HIS HEADPHONES.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Sure. What do you need?

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: I need a gun. And I don’t have a lot of time to get it. You were the only person I could trust.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Whoa.

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: And has guns.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: (taking a drag) Shit, man- you can pretty much buy one anywhere.

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: I tried to get one on my own. I don’t have any money- wait... (digging crumpled bills from his pocket) I mean, I’ve got- but my I.D. is-  175 176 177 58.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Hold on. Are you a junkie, dude?

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: No. No, I shouldn't have just...

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: (realizing) Oh, wait. Shit. It’s about that time... Ben gives a subtle nod, takes another drag.

dialogues.speaker: BEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Yeah. Hop in brother. Ben heads to his truck.

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: I should take my car...

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: You gassed up? I’m in the boonies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Bonneville’s headlights project onto kicked-up dust f Ben’s truck. The tree-lined road vanishes into pitch blac EXT. BEN’S HOUSE - NIGHT 176 The two vehicles pull past a shotgun shack up to a single story prefab house. Dwight parks twenty feet short. INT. BEDROOM - BEN’S HOUSE - PRE-DAWN 177 HALLWAY LIGHTS CLICK ON. Ben leads Dwight into the sparse earthy room, neatly kept if a bit dank.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Hey- I got something..

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: What’s that? Ben opens a JUNK DRAWER in a old bureau, rifles through i

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: You remember when James Henry’s brother had the stripper at his party? At his shop?  59.

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: Haven't thought that far back in a while.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: I got a Polaroid of me and you with the stripper. It’s hilarious- we’re both terrified.

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: Ben. I need to hurry. Ben nods, shoving the drawer closed, turning to two METAL LOCKERS along the wall.

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Do you hunt?

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Very little. Ben pulls a MAGNETIC BOX from behind a locker, shaking ou KEYS and turning them in the locks.

dialogues.speaker: BEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: More into target shooting. What do you need it for?

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: I’d rather...

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Oh- no, man. The less I know, the better. What do you need out of the gun. At range? Close quarters? Dwight stands at a loss as Ben swings open the doors.

dialogues.speaker: BEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Close up or far away?

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: Probably close. I don’t know. Hopefully not at all.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Roger that. See what I’ve got... (running his hand along the racks) An Enfield mark three, Circuit Judge, a Mosin... He pulls out a vintage BOLT-ACTION RIFLE, feeling the wei  60.

dialogues.speaker: BEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: ..-which is my current favorite. Bolt action, heavy, and the surplus ammo is cheap. He sets it on the bed and wipes his nose.

dialogues.speaker: BEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The AK, Mossberg- might be a bit much. What do you weigh?

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: Don’t know.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: ...the Sterling might jam up on you. Ben pulls out a VINTAGE SUB MACHINE GUN.

dialogues.speaker: BEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It’ll clear a room, though. Ah. He replaces the sub machine gun, removing a bulky automat pistol from the cabinet.

dialogues.speaker: BEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I picked this up this year. Steyr nineteen-twelve. Shoots it’s own nine mil cartridge, great shape- but you gotta load it slide-back with a stripper clip.

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: Nothing that’s special to you- the least expensive, as long as it works...

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: The World War I and II models are bring-backs- no papers, no import marks. But you don’t want a bolt- action... Dwight stews in ignorance. Ben reads it, selecting a MINI RIFLE.

dialogues.speaker: BEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Here. The Mini Fourteen. Gunshow- no papers. It’s a carbine- that just means it’s short. Semi-auto- it fires every time you pull the trigger- twenty rounds. Very reliable. Plus, I got ammo here.  61. Ben expertly loads a clip and assumes a firing position, trigger finger extended against the guard.

dialogues.speaker: BEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Recognize it? Dwight shakes ‘no’.

dialogues.speaker: BEN, (CONT'D)
