dialogues.text: It’s the A-Team gun. From the show. Their’s were stainless... Ben presents the rifle. Dwight grabs it, but Ben holds fi

dialogues.speaker: BEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (nodding) What’s up with that? Dwight follows Ben’s gaze to a BLOOD STAIN on his SHIRT A PANTS.

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: Oh, that’s not- it’s from an arrow. It’s stitched up.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Not so well, huh. Ben lets go of the rifle. Dwight feels the weight.

dialogues.speaker: BEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So then, you’re already in this?

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: Yes. Ben locks eyes with sincere concern.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Because I was just blowing smoke up your ass, bro. Preparing a speech in my head to stop you from whatever crazy shit you’re about to do.

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: It’s already done...

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Thought about calling the cops.

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: Please don’t. Not yet. I don’t have a speech- just please trust me.  178 62.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: I do, bro. But I can’t send you off like this. I could teach you. CQB, man! Surprise, speed, violence of action...

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: I just need somewhere quiet right now.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: I’ve got sixteen acres. Follow the road we came in on ‘till it ends- you'll see the targets.

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: You right handed? Dwight nods ‘yes’.

dialogues.speaker: BEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Real quick. Keep the safety off. Wherever your eyes look, the gun follows. And keep your distance- or it can get sloppy.

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: I know. You ever killed anyone?

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: (shutting the lockers) Two on purpose.

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: (nodding thoughtfully) Can I get a thing of water? EXT. SECLUDED AREA - BEN’S PROPERTY - EARLY MORNING 178 A dead end clearing littered with SANDBAGS, TRAFFIC CONES SHOT-UP TARGETS and a ROTTING PICNIC TABLE. A field of ta grass flanks one side. CLOSE-UP: A WATER BOTTLE is placed on grass. ON DWIGHT, rising with the MINI-14 RIFLE, like a seven ye old about to jump off the high-dive for the first time. ON THE TRUNK OF THE BONNEVILLE.  179 180 63.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The passenger door hangs open. Dwight takes a knee, stretching in to unlatch the glove box. He pockets the CELL PHONE, draws a breath and POPS THE TR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dwight scurries to the trunk as it’s pushed up by Teddy, emerging disoriented in a sheen of filth and sweat.

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: Stay in the trunk. Teddy swallows air, squinting in the daylight, seeing the rifle trained on his chest.

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY
dialogues.text: (hoarse) That's easy, my leg is broke. Dwight stands mute, the bottle of water by his feet.

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (weakly snapping his finger) That for me? Dwight wiggles a firmer grip around the rifle.

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: Were you coming for me or for her?

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: You came to my sister's house. Who were you coming for?

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY
dialogues.text: Look, man. You.

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: Then how come you didn’t just call the police? Send me to jail?

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY
dialogues.text: Same as you. Keeping it ‘in-house’. Dwight tosses the water bottle, TEDDY snatches it from th air, uncaps it and chugs...  64.

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: What if I surrender? Teddy raises his eyebrows, chugging. He empties the bottl and tosses it to the ground.

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY
dialogues.text: (ecstatic breath) I accept.

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: Please, dammit. To the police- I'll plead guilty.

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY
dialogues.text: You don’t get to do what you did and just lock yourself up. Shit, I'd give you props if he wasn’t my brother. Or if he had it coming.

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: If Wade didn’t deserve it, then nobody ever has. Teddy rubs his face, looks off.

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Which one are you, again?

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY
dialogues.text: Teddy.

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: And who was the boy in the limousine?

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY
dialogues.text: You totaled it. That’s my livelihood... Dwight waits patiently for the answer.

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Just a boy. Not a concern.

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: When I let him out, he said something about Wade. That he didn’t hurt anyone...

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY
dialogues.text: Yeah, well- (chuckling) Coupla dead negroes might disagree. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (unsmiling) He just meant Wade didn’t kill your parents.

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: Not true.

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY
dialogues.text: Well that settles it, then. Dwight anxiously finds a new stance, flushing red.

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That’s how this works, man. The one with the gun gets to tell the truth. Problem is, you don’t know shit.

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: Tell me.

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY
dialogues.text: (quiet, taunting) I should’ve done the time.

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: (raising the rifle) Are you saying you killed them?

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY
dialogues.text: Nope.

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: Forget this. Dwight CLICKS THE SAFETY, taking aim at Teddy’s arm.

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY
dialogues.text: (flinching, blurting) What‘er you tryin’ to do?! WHAT’ER YOU TRYIN’ TO DO!? DWIGHT SQUEEZES THE TRIGGER - PANG! - AND MISSES.

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (exhilarated) HOT DAMN! Fish in a barrel!

dialogues.speaker: STOP IT
dialogues.text: Teddy settles, suppressing a smug grin.  66.

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Whatever you're saying, say it.

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY
dialogues.text: I didn’t do it. Wade didn’t do it. Our father, Big Wade, shot your dad. As was his right.

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: His right?

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY
dialogues.text: You don’t fuck with a man’s wife. His family.

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: Whatever my dad did, he did with your mom. They made a mistake. Togeth-

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY
dialogues.text: SHIT’S NOT A MISTAKE.

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: Whatever it was, both my parents are dead-

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY
dialogues.text: Your dad got what he deserved. Your mom was just in the car- that was a fuckup. I’1l give you that...

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: I don’t want your opinion on things. If it’s true about Wade- why did he...?

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY
dialogues.text: Big Wade had cancer. We couldn’t let him die in prison. I would've done the time, but I had two strikes. Would’ve been life with no parole. Little Wade could take a plea... You smoke? Teddy watches intently as Dwight, lost in thought, lets t rifle barrel drift downward. Dwight pulls out the CELL PH

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: Call them.

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY
dialogues.text: Who’s them? The cops?  67.

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: Your family. Teddy gestures for the phone. Dwight cautiously lobs it o Teddy catches it and checks the screen.

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY
dialogues.text: What do you want me to say?

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: We're all going to meet up- somewhere public- and it’s going to end.

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY
dialogues.text: Okay. He dials and waits.

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: Don’t say my name and don’t say anything about a gun. We’re in Kentucky.

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY
dialogues.text: (surveying) You ever been to Kentucky? Dwight blinks, re-focusing down the rifle sights.

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (into cell phone) It’s me. Call me back. NOW. (to Dwight) Not picking up. May I call the house? Dwight nods his approval. Teddy dials and waits.

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (into phone) Hey. Yeah- shut up. I’m fine...just my leg. I’m with him, he’s here. Not now, he wants to meet- fine. I'll try, but we just went through it. (to Dwight) She wants to talk to you.

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY
dialogues.text: My sister. She’s bossy...  68.

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: Throw it. Teddy pivots the phone in his hand, tweaking its position

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY
dialogues.text: I would- the signal’s weak. We can’t blow this- just take it... He extends the phone with one hand.

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It’s fine. You can point that thing right at my face. I’m not moving.

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: Turn around. Look away. Teddy shifts his weight around, looking back into the tru

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY
dialogues.text: Keep your finger on the trigger... Dwight approaches, two hands gripping the rifle, pointing directly at the back of Teddy's head.

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It’s over as far as I’m concerned. (towards the phone) You hear that, sis? Dwight reaches for the phone, steps on the discarded wate bottle. CRUNCH.

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: .--don’t go starting ANY SHIT-

dialogues.speaker: THE GROUND, ELBOWING HIM HARD TO THE FACE.
dialogues.text: Teddy snatches the gun and SLAMS THE PHONE INTO DWIGHT’S STUNNED FACE.

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: THERE’S NOBODY HOME, STUPID FUCK! They’re huntin’... He backs off fast, rising with the gun.  69.

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: YES. FUCK! My fucking legs are asleep... Teddy wobbles back to the rear bumper and sits. He pulls slide handle and ejects a cartridge. Dwight grimaces, his trembling...

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: I'll die. I should. But my sister never did anything. Just tell me...

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY
dialogues.text: You bet. I got the gun, you get the truth. But not to satisfy your fucking curiosity, Dwight. Teddy rises and hovers over Dwight with a cold stare.

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Just know that the man who killed your parents didn’t die by your hands. He smoked and he drank and he- guess he didn’t fuck cuz of the cancer- but he watched all his favorite TV shows and he died a free man. You'll die like your whore father did... ...Shot in the fucking face. Or first do you wanna open up that belly? See your guts steam? Teddy raises the M-14 barrel to Dwight’s stomach. Dwight drowns in dread.

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Must have a little in there since you took Wade from us. (quiet, sinister) And for that, your sister and tho- SWIP. THE AIR BETWEEN THEM IS DISTURBED VIOLENTLY. Dwight and Teddy share confusion. KOOSH. A distant thundering sound. Teddy looks to the far tree line, searching. Dwight looks to Teddy as HIS HEAD SMACKS APART AT THE BAS THE NECK AND JAW.  70. KOOSH. Another thundering sound as Teddy’s body collapses the side.

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: -.-wait. Dwight sits up, face smattered with blood, finding where Teddy's eyes were trained.

dialogues.speaker: BEN IS WALKING BRISKLY ACROSS THE FIELD AIMING HIS MOSIN
dialogues.text: ACTION RIFLE. Wearing camouflage hunting overalls, he eje a shell and loads the chamber.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: (echoing across the field)

dialogues.speaker: JUST THE ONE
dialogues.text: Dwight nods ‘yes’, his chest heaving. Ben is too far for subtle gestures.

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: (echoing back) YES. Ben safeties his weapon, still bridging the distance.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: SORRY. COULDN'T SHOOT ‘TILL HE

dialogues.speaker: MY END AT LEAST.
dialogues.text: Ben reaches the clearing, pulls the clip and sets the Mos on the picnic table.

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: His head...

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: That’s what bullets do. Dwight watches in awe as Ben scoops the Mini-14 from the ground, pops the clip and safeties it beside the Mosin.

dialogues.speaker: BEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Jesus man, I am not impressed. Told you to keep your distance- you missed from two yards? Ben grabs Teddy’s corpse under the armpits, waits for Dwi

dialogues.speaker: BEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Let’s go man. I’d like him off my property. C’mon.  71. Dwight dusts off and grabs the corpse by the ankles. They lift and carry.

dialogues.speaker: BEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This Wade Cleland?

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: (straining) His older brother. Wade’s already dead.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: (noticing the blood) Wipe your face off. He’s probably got hepatitis. They drop the body in the open trunk.

dialogues.speaker: BEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (re: Teddy’s cell phone) Pick that up, throw it in here. Dwight does as he’s told.

dialogues.speaker: BEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Don’t forget to wipe it down before you get rid of it. You got the keys? Dwight checks his pockets and nods ‘yes’.

dialogues.speaker: BEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Show ‘em to me. Dwight presents the keys. Ben shuts the trunk firmly.

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: (pointing) What about the rest of his head? There’s BRAIN TISSUE AND CARTILAGE in the nearby grass.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Coyotes will get that. (second look) Long as there’s no teeth...

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: (wiping face with shirt) They won’t let it end. Not now.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Yeah, well. I’m switching you to buckshot.  181 182 72. EXT. SECLUDED AREA - BEN’S PROPERTY - LATER 181 A CRUDE STACK OF JUGS AND CRATES BLOWS APART. Dwight FIRES a CIRCUIT JUDGE REVOLVING RIFLE. He lowers the barrel, pops the cylinder and tosses the sp shells, looking to Ben.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: It’s doesn’t have the stopping power of a twelve gauge- but you seem comfortable with it. Dwight nods, drifting. Ben swaps guns as Dwight TUNES OUT.

dialogues.speaker: BEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Shoots slugs too- but you wouldn’t hit anything. Only five shots though, so the Steyr is your secondary- backup. Another eight rounds, and stopping power- Ben steps to Dwight until his wandering eyes make contact

dialogues.speaker: BEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This is personal, I know. But that’s how you’ll fail. No talking. No speeches. If you point the gun, you shoot the gun. Dwight nods. EXT. DRIVEWAY - BEN’S HOUSE - DAY 182 Dwight and Ben load the guns and a pack in the Bonneville

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: This should do you.

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: Where’s the closest car repair?

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Well, once you're back to the main road- closest one’s about 20 miles. But that’s east. I assume you’re heading west. It’s just a gas station, though- watcha need?  183 184 73.

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: It‘ll be fine. But do you have some food I could take? (holding his belly) Think I’m going to pass out...

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Yeah, man. Dwight watches Ben double time it to the house. INT. KITCHEN - BEN’S HOUSE - DAY (CONTINUOUS) 183 Ben piles SNACKS from cabinets into a SHOPPING BAG. From pantry he pulls packets of VACUUM SEALED FOOD. EXT. BEN’S HOUSE - DAY (MOMENTS LATER) 184 Dwight shuts the Bonneville’s door and turns to Ben, approaching with the grocery bag.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Threw a few MREs in there. Dwight accepts the bag and hands Ben the OLD YEARBOOK.

dialogues.speaker: BEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (flipping through) Nice! I lost mine, or shot it up...

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: I wish I didn’t bring all this to you.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: (closing yearbook) It’s come and gone. Plus, I’m glad you did. You'd be dead otherwise.

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: You know what I mean.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: If it were my family, I might do the same. I don’t know. But I’m not helping ‘cus this is right. This is ugly, man. The two stand in silence, acknowledging the weight.  185 186 187 74.

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: Hey. If you ever do come across that Polaroid- of us with the stripper- Ben smiles.

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Do me a favor?

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: Destroy it? Ben’s smile fades.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dwight drives west, squinting peacefully into the sun, wi from open windows scattering his hair. ON THE RADIO: He powers it up and SCANS STATIONS. A LOCAL OLDIES STATION CRACKLES THROUGH THE SPEAKERS.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. PICKUP TRUCK - BEN’S HOUSE - DAY 186 The truck cab is packed with HUNTING GEAR. Ben tucks TWO RIFLE CASES behind the seats and turns the ignition. THE ENGINE DOESN’T TURN OVER, NOT EVEN A CLICK. He pulls the hood latch and hops out. EXT. PICKUP TRUCK - BEN’S HOUSE - DAY (CONTINUOUS) 187 Ben lifts the hood, revealing an EMPTY BATTERY TRAY WITH LOOSE HANGING CONNECTOR CABLES.  188 189 190 191 192 193 75.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Ha.

dialogues.speaker: THE OLDIES SONG REMAINS.
dialogues.text: The Bonneville pulls into the lot of a greasy spoon cafe’

dialogues.speaker: THE OLDIES SONG REMAINS.
dialogues.text: Dwight unfolds a paper napkin at a booth. Before him, a C STEAK and a GLASS OF RED WINE. INT. BEDROOM - BEN’S HOUSE - DAY 190 Ben returns RIFLES to their locker, looks off...

dialogues.speaker: THE OLDIES SONG SURGES.
dialogues.text: Back on the road, Dwight heads into the horizon. INT. KITCHEN - BEN’S HOUSE - DAY 192

dialogues.speaker: FLASHES OF BLINDING BLUE LIGHT WITH MELTING, BUBBLING LAY
dialogues.text: It’s a POLAROID PICTURE BURNING IN A MICROWAVE. Ben leans against the kitchen counter, watching the show a TALL-BOY in hand. He drinks.

dialogues.speaker: THE OLDIES SONG IS DROWNED BY HARSH WIND AND PASSING TRAF
dialogues.text: Dwight leans against the Bonneville, VOMITING on the road LOW STRINGS BUILD.  194 195 196 197 198 199 200 201 76.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A panoramic view of rolling-hill country.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Bonneville turns off the main road and up an incline.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON THE CAR WHEELS, from CRACKED PAVEMENT TO RAW DIRT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dwight backs the Bonneville into an off road clearing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dwight darkens. He cuts the engine. FROM THE BACK SEAT: Dwight opens the rear door and gather his WEAPONS. ON THE KEYS, STILL DANGLING IN THE IGNITION, as Dwight sh the door and passes the window. He places a FALLEN BRANCH against the car, shading the interior. Then another.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A narrow, rutted road leads to a weathered brick entrance with an iron gate secured by a HEAVY CHAIN and PADLOCK. A worn, hand painted PLAQUE reads: ‘CLELAND’

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dwight slides the Circuit Judge rifle and the Steyr pisto under a low, twisted fence. He tosses his backpack over a straddles the sagging wire, rolling over and off... .«.-HIS SHOES HIT THE DIRT ONTO CLELAND PROPERTY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TRACKING WITH DWIGHT, traversing dense woods, rifle in ha  202 203 204 205 206 207 208 77.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dwight crouches, getting the lay of the land. A rustic single story house sits in a half acre clearing. two-car garage lies beyond, its doors obstructed by a BOA TRAILER parked on sunken concrete. Four generation’s worth of ARTIFACTS clutter the property

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WIDE, FROM AFAR, Dwight starts towards the quiet house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dwight rounds the back with trained eyes, moving past an TOW TRUCK, its load covered in BLUE TARP. THE BACK SCREEN DOOR, FRAMED IN WOOD. Dwight leans close, listening inside. He cracks it open, turning the interior door handle. LOCK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dwight hugs the mossy siding, ducking under a window. He sets the rifle down, cupping the glass for a view.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dwight stalks towards the front door. A DISTANT NOISE. He pivots to the woods and listens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THROUGH A WINDOW, Dwight appears, squinting into the dark interior cast in green from surrounding foliage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dwight opens the back screen door, widens his stance and VIOLENTLY KICKS THE INTERIOR DOOR. The screen SMACKS his with each LOUD IMPACT.  209 78. The door holds firm. Spooked by his failed breach, Dwight clears out, the screen door SLAMMING behind him. He scampers behind the tow truck and readies the rifle, h grip arm resting on a fender. RIFLE SIGHTS ON THE BACK DOOR... Nobody comes. He turns to the tarp behind the truck, weighted by a CIND BLOCK. He kicks it over and lifts the tarp. UNDER THE TARP: The WHITE LIMOUSINE wreckage, scorched an half-cannibalized. THUNK. Dwight plants the CINDER BLOCK, propping open the screen door. He leans the rifle by the frame and backs of With a running start, Dwight delivers a POWERFUL KICK. The INTERIOR DOOR CAVES INWARD SEVERAL INCHES and the fra comes loose. He backs up further and runs...

dialogues.speaker: THE BACK DOOR SMASHES OPEN AND THE FRAME GIVES.
dialogues.text: The rifle barrel pushes inside, Dwight guiding it.

dialogues.speaker: HAND HELD WITH DWIGHT AS HE SEARCHES
dialogues.text: DOWN A HALLWAY. It’s musty and dark, THICK DRAPES block t daylight. THROUGH THE NARROW KITCHEN with JUNK FOOD WRAPPERS and da appliances. INTO THE DINING AREA with an oval TABLE, three ASHTRAYS, chairs piled with NEWSPAPERS and a wood laminate CREDENZA THROUGH THE LIVING ROOM, past a feline SCRATCHING POST, a corduroy COUCH, COFFEE TABLE, RECLINER and an oversized projection TV. INTO THE MASTER BEDROOM with a QUEEN BED, STUFFED ANIMALS a COT. BACK OUT AND DOWN A HALLWAY, ducking in and out of a BATHROOM, past an IRONING BOARD against the wall.  210 211 212 213 79. INTO A SECOND BEDROOM with two DOUBLE BEDS, a small TELEVISION and a GAME CONSOLE... AND BACK INTO THE HALLWAY- the full tour. Dwight lowers t rifle in the light of the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT CRASHES THE RIFLE BUTT THROUGH THE GLASS OF THE SI
dialogues.text: DOOR. He reaches in, unlatching the dead bolt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dwight moves through a mudroom stacked with BOXES, swingi his rifle into the garage. Scattered LIMOUSINE PARTS, TOOLS, a REFRIGERATOR, and a f sized MATTRESS and BOX SPRING. BLOOD SPLATTER above the baseboard bleeds through FRESH W PAINT. On the floor lies a ROLLER, an ALUMINUM TRAY and a OF WHITE PAINT. ON DWIGHT, turning to the near wall... OVER HIS SHOULDER: HALF A DOZEN RIFLES ON RACKS, encased the glass of an ANTIQUE CABINET. There are TWO EMPTY RACKS IN THE CASE. His shoulders sink, gazing at the arsenal before him. He turns a KEY in the lock and the door drifts open. He turns to the bed. Atop a MILK CRATE ‘end table’ are scraps of TIN-FOIL, BOT CAPS and a cloudy GLASS PIPE. Dwight PULLS THE TOP SHEET FROM THE MATTRESS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dwight backs out the side door dragging the bedsheet, the CLATTERING guns wrapped inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dwight opens the drapes, cross-lighting stagnant dust.  80. He unhooks THREE ANTIQUE RIFLES hanging above the televis He runs his hands under the couch. He pulls open a side table drawer. With a knee to the floor, he searches the credenza. He stands, noticing a BLINKING ANSWERING MACHINE on top. He hits ‘PLAY’.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS, (ON ANSWERING MACHINE)
dialogues.text: Teddy, check in. We took the truck. Headed to the shore, left you the map and your charger. William is with Sherri. She is not happy about all this. Might need to do something about her too. This is a fucking mess. Erase this if you get it. We’ll pick William up on the way back. Should be there Thursday night. I hope to God you're not dead. Erase this if you get it. BEEP. Dwight finds the PHONE CHARGER and MAP on the dining tabl It’s his map from the Bonneville, with a line from Delawa to Virginia.

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY
dialogues.text: (muffled, wind whipped) TEDDY: ...he’s here. No. Listen. Not now, he wants to meet- fine. I’1ll try, but we've already been through it. She wants to talk to you. DWIGHT: Who? TEDDY: My sister. She’s bossy... DWIGHT: Throw it... TEDDY: Shit. The signal’s weak. I don’t want to blow this- just take it. It’s fine. You can point that thing right at my face. I’m not moving. DWIGHT: Turn around. Look away. TEDDY: Keep your finger on the trigger... It’s over as far as I’m concerned. You hear that, sis? Don’t go starting ANY

dialogues.speaker: SHIT- AN OVERMODULATED SCUFFLE
dialogues.text: TEDDY: THERE’S NOBODY HOME, STUPID FUCK! They’re hun- CLICK. BEEP. Dwight has his finger on the ‘STOP’ button. He presses ‘PLAY ALL’ and continues searching...  214 215 81. CLICK. BEEP.

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY, (ON ANSWERING MACHINE)
dialogues.text: Hey, when you’re home stay there. Had to swap out a tire to tow her four down- hitched up now, should be there by eight or nine. We'll take his car. Call me on my cell. And keep Carl in check. BEEP.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dwight circles the bed, checking under the mattress.

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE VOICE, (ON ANSWERING MACHINE)
dialogues.text: Hello. This is officer Downey with Community Corrections calling to reach Wade Cleland... He slides open a bedside drawer and removes a NICKEL PLAT REVOLVER. He tests the weight and tucks it in his belt.

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE VOICE, (ON ANSWERING MACHINE)
dialogues.text: (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You had a post release and urinalysis scheduled this morning which you did not attend, I’m gonna need you to contact me immediately and make that up this week to avoid a violation. Don’t wanna start off on the wrong foot... BLACK. A CLOSET DOOR OPENS, Dwight pushes aside hanging clothes: VACUUM CLEANER, STUFFED ANIMALS, lots of REEBOKS

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE VOICE, (ON ANSWERING MACHINE)
dialogues.text: (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can reach me at four three four, two nine five, seven one nine four, Community Corrections, Probation and Parole District 9. Officer Downey. BEEP.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dwight checks the mattresses. One BED is messy, tucked in corner with a metal frame and headboard.  216 217 218 219 82. The other an AIR MATTRESS with pressed sheets and a CARTO CIGARETTES by the pillow.

dialogues.speaker: CARL, (ON ANSWERING MACHINE)
dialogues.text: Pick up. Pick up! She was not there- he was. Pick up... Dwight’s eyes settle on a HOMEMADE BANNER draped above th door frame with letters drawn in marker: ‘Welcome Home Wade!!!’

dialogues.speaker: CARL, (ON ANSWERING MACHINE)
dialogues.text: .--I’m not saying anything on this, but I need a ride and Teddy is not with- CLICK. BEEP.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bedsheet lies open by the back door. Dwight tosses th hung antiques onto the HEAP OF GUNS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dwight drags the bedsheet down an incline, coming upon a rusted gate bordering a CRUDE GRAVE SITE. LIMESTONE MEMORIALS, GRANITE HEADSTONES and SLABS OF SLAT sit shaded by a tree, crooked from its roots. Near the edge, FRESHLY CHURNED DIRT with DRIED WILD FLOWE and a LIQUOR BOTTLE in place of a stone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dwight shovels dirt under a canopy of trees. He pulls the bedsheet of guns into the ditch and fills it He walks over loose dirt, packing it down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Glistening with muddy sweat, Dwight pulls a cup from a cabinet, filling it from the tap and chugging water. He refills it.  220 221 222 223 224 83.

dialogues.speaker: A GRA
dialogues.text: HEADSTONE: ‘WADE MARSHAL CLELAND SR.’ Urine desecrates the grave. A healthy amount of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON THE WELCOME MAT, Dwight props a GLASS JAR of coins, ta and hardware against the front door. He takes shelter behind a PILED FURNITURE BUNKER, bracing against the wall, his rifle barrel resting on a couch pil Dwight waits patiently in the dark.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The BUSY DRONE of night creatures. PUSHING IN ON THE PITCH BLACK HOUSE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dwight’s heavy, drifting eyes.

dialogues.speaker: SHADOWS IN EVERY DIRECTION.
dialogues.text: Dwight springs up with his weight against the wall. His eyes sharpen, his breaths ease- in through the nose, through the mouth. The rifle is trained steadily on the d He hunts for a trace of sound or motion. But there is none. He steps in for a better angle of view. Still no trace. He ducks past the window and drops down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dwight crawls through the kitchen and out the back door.  225 226 227 84.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dwight jogs in a crouch around the house, sweeping with h eyes through the rifle sights. He lines-up the front porch. Nothing but night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dwight enters from the kitchen, approaching the PHANTOM L He drops to all fours and traces the lamp cord to an OUTL Between the plug and socket is a SMALL BEIGE DEVICE, like thermostat, but marked with hours instead of degrees. Wri in brown font: ‘Intermatic TIME-ALL’ It’s set for 9PM. From his low vantage point, Dwight notices a stack of BOO under the coffee table. He pulls out two dusty vinyl PHOTO ALBUMS. He cocks his head and listens. Then settles on the floor against the recliner and flips through...

dialogues.speaker: THE PHOTO ALBUM
dialogues.text: A photo timeline of the Clelands. Vintage black and white faded color prints and stained Polaroids. From stoic, depression era hunters to Teddy and his limousines. Pelts and guns. A man and a woman. The man sick. The woman pregnant. The woman with a baby, others wear black. A young boy beside a slain deer, with indifferent eyes...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dwight sits asleep on the floor against the recliner, the album across his lap. The lamp’s warm glow clashes agains the morning blue. HUM...TICK. The lamp turns off. Dwight wakes in the cold light.  228 229 230 231 232 233 85.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dwight pulls the bedsheet off the air mattress, sets the cigarette carton back on top.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TRACKING WITH DWIGHT, back through the woods, the sheet o his shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PUSHING IN ON THE BONNEVILLE, half camouflaged with branc ON THE TRUNK as it unlatches and bobs. Dwight lifts it op wincing at the escaping smell. He spreads the bedsheet on the ground, holds his breath a lunges into the trunk, grappling with TEDDY'S BODY until slumps over the edge and onto the sheet. Dwight gasps upward for air, pockets Teddy’s CELL PHONE a shuts the trunk. He wraps the body.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dwight struggles with THE BODY, caught in the fence by it own weight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dwight drags THE BODY by the bedsheet, torn and muddy wit blood pooling at one end. He’s exhausted, sweating profusely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON DWIGHT’S FACE, as he shovels dirt. ON THE GRAVE he’s digging, by the edge of the gated plot. WIDER, Dwight stands in the ditch, hips at ground level. pulls THE BODY into the grave. ON DWIGHT’S FACE, as he shovels.  234 235 236 86. A MUFFLED PULSE stops him mid swing. AGAIN, clearly now- A TELEPHONE RING.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON THE PHONE. Dwight stomps to a halt, catching his breat the ANSWERING MACHINE ENGAGES.

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY'S VOICE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (answering machine) You've reached the Cleland residence- drop it like it’s hot. BEEP. DEAD AIR. FOUR NUMERIC TONES. Dwight tenses.

dialogues.speaker: ANSWERING MACHINE
dialogues.text: (electronic menu voice) You have-no-new messages. You have- five-saved mes- THREE NUMERIC TONES. Dwight steps closer with wide eyes. ANSWERING MACHINE (CONT’D) (electronic menu voice) You have-no-messages. A SUSTAINED DIAL TONE... CLICK. Dwight stares, shaken. He fishes in his pocket, sets Teddy’s phone on the dining table and plugs in the charger. Fumbling with the power connector, Dwight scowls until th phone CHIRPS AFFIRMATIVE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dwight wiggles a SLAB OF ROCK flush with the dirt. He PAINTS ‘TEDDY’ on it with the roller and tray.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dwight swings his rifle in the hallway, testing the width  237 238 239 240 241 242 87. INT. MASTER BEDROOM —- CLELAND HOME - DAY 237 Dwight shuts the closet door and pinches the drapes, reac through them to open the bottom window pane. He kneels behind the bed. RIFLE SIGHTS THROUGH THE DOOR, INTO THE LIVING ROOM HALL.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dwight closes the drapes and turns on a table lamp, leavi the door slightly ajar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dwight steps to the ironing board against the wall. He mo it aside and discovers a narrow doorway into a utility ar

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dwight enters the dark and pulls a hanging chain. A fluorescent light warms up, flickering above a compact washing machine and utility sink. DRIED BLOOD coats the s rim, a bag of soiled clothes sits on the washer. A silver CHARM NECKLACE dangles from a wire shelf.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON THE CELLPHONE, atop the dining table. It CHIRPS again, charger unplugged. Dwight rises behind it. He disconnects the phone and arranges the charger on the table as he found it beside the map. He dials a number on Teddy’s cell phone, referring to a L on the house phone. He waits. The house phone RINGS... The answering machine CLICKS AND SPEWS SHRILL AUDIO FEEDB

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dwight stands thirty feet from the house, the phone press to his ear, waiting for a BEEP.  243 244 245 246 247 248 249 88.

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: (into phone) Hello. It’s me...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON THE WELCOME MAT: Dwight removes the GLASS JAR from aga the door.

dialogues.speaker: LOW, BROODING STRINGS.
dialogues.text: The furniture bunker is gone. Dwight tucks to the wall an sinks to the floor, the rifle in his lap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FIREFLIES BLINK in the brush as the house darkens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The night sky envelopes the surrounding woods. THE LOW STRINGS BUILD.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Black trees sway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Through the rusted gate, HEADLIGHTS APPEAR around a bend skip off the dirt. THE STRINGS INTENSIFY.

dialogues.speaker: A FAMILIAR BUZZ...CLICK.
dialogues.text: The PHANTOM LAMP illuminates. DOWN THE HALL, Dwight waits.  89. The distant CLINK OF A GATE. The RUMBLE OF TIRES. Dwight brings his knees to his chest, his feet flat again the carpet. He pulls out Teddy’s cell phone, presses a button and wai OUTSIDE, A VEHICLE PULLS UP. Dwight backs into the dark, pressing another button. THE HOUSE PHONE RINGS. MUFFLED VOICES OUTSIDE. RUNNING FEET.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (through door) It’s the phone!

dialogues.speaker: CARL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (through door) Move! KEYS CLANK AGAINST THE DOOR.

dialogues.speaker: THE DOOR LATCHES OPEN
dialogues.text: ON DWIGHT, shadowed out of view, quietly closing the phon and slipping it away. THE RINGING STOPS as the trio reaches the phone.

dialogues.speaker: CARL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Fuck!

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: There’s a message!

dialogues.speaker: HOPE
dialogues.text: Go. Play it! Chris presses ‘PLAY’. ON DWIGHT, DOWN THE HALLWAY, dripping sweat. He raises th Circuit Judge Rifle, finds a firm grip. Chris, Hope and Carl gather around the table, listening intently to the message. THEY’RE ALL IN HIS SIGHTS. CLICK. BEEP.  90. DWIGHT’S VOICE (ON ANSWERING MACHINE) Hello. It’s me. Dwight Evans...

dialogues.speaker: HOPE
dialogues.text: Shut the fuck up!

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT, (ON ANSWERING MACHINE)
dialogues.text: Wade is dead. Teddy is dead too. He told me everything. I think. Chris weeps. Carl BLURTS but Hope SLAPS him quiet. DWIGHT’S VOICE (ON ANSWERING MACHINE) I didn’t kill him- well, I guess I did. It doesn’t matter. By my count that’s two of yours and two of mine. I don’t know how this ends, but I'd like it to, uh... Or it can keep going. I just need my sister to be left out if this-

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: (erupting) THAT’S WHY WE’RE GOING TO

dialogues.speaker: PITTSBURGH YOU SONA-
dialogues.text: BOOM! CARL’S CHEST POPS OPEN, SPLATTERING BLOOD ON THE ANSWERING MACHINE AND ACROSS THE DINING AREA. Carl keels over YELLING THROUGH CLENCHED TEETH as Dwight steps from the shadows.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: THAT’S HIM! DWIGHT’S VOICE (ON ANSWERING MACHINE) I have Teddy’s phone. Dwight aims and fires. BOOM. A MISS. The bulk of the buckshot SPLINTERS THE TABLE, som it GRAZES HOPE, HER SLEEVE TEARING WITH BLOODY MIST.

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: (quick, instinctual) Sorry. HE CHECKS HIS AIM AND BLOWS ANOTHER HOLE IN CARL’S SIDE.  91.

dialogues.speaker: HOPE
dialogues.text: WE’RE GONNA FUCKING KILL YOU! DWIGHT’S VOICE (ON ANSWERING MACHINE) You'll find his body in the yard with some family. Dwight nods, showing teeth. Carl slumps in the corner.

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: Wish you woulda... He aims, alternating between Chris and Hope. DWIGHT’S VOICE (ON ANSWERING MACHINE) Call it if you want to talk this through... Tears flow down Dwight’s flushed face.

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: (trembling) You people... DWIGHT’S VOICE (ON ANSWERING MACHINE) Sorry to bother you at home. CLICK. BEEP. Chris looks to the wall above the television.

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: Guns are gone. Buried them. He shows the nickel plated revolver tucked in his belt.

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This one too. Chris looks to the RECLINER. Hope turns her head ever so slightly, eyes drifting to th front door: THROUGH THE FRONT DOOR: OUT OF DWIGHT’S VIEW STANDS THE B grasping his hand held video game console. He creeps back towards the PARKED TRUCK.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Don’t shoot us.

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I've been here a while. Waiting.  92. The Boy delicately opens the cab door and removes a DOUBL BARRELED SHOTGUN from a GUN RACK.

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Trying to think of reasons not to do this- to end your family. There’s a thousand. But there’s one why I should.

dialogues.speaker: HOPE
dialogues.text: Fine. We'll leave her out. Dwight looks up from his sights.

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: How ca-—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dwight defiantly attempts to stand, bleeding from his rib

dialogues.speaker: GO
dialogues.text: The Young Boy walks in closer as Dwight staggers to his f

dialogues.speaker: HOPE
dialogues.text: (to Dwight) Your whole family will die... The Young Boy, William, shakes his head ‘no’ as Chris ste towards the door.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: (crying, still walking) I don’t want to. As William approaches, Dwight grabs the Circuit Judge fro the floor and swings it like a sword, sweeping and SMACKI THE BARREL OF WILLIAM’S SHOTGUN. BOOM.

dialogues.speaker: PLASTER FROM THE CEILING RAINS DOWN ON DWIGHT AND WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Chris reaches the recliner in a crouch as Dwight puts her his sights.

dialogues.speaker: STOP.
dialogues.text: Chris stands slowly.  93. Hope holds her bleeding arm, exuding pure hatred. William stands stunned with a loose grip on the shotgun. ON THE SHOTGUN: TWO SMOKING BARRELS, TWO TRIGGERS.

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (calmly, to William) I don’t know much about guns. But I think I have more bullets than you.

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: (to Hope) If he dies tonight, your father killed him. Your father killed everyone here. Dwight lifts his shirt, exposing the GUSHING HOLE IN HIS SIDE.

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (calmly, to William) I think you did your job, William. I still gotta finish up, though. Fast, I think. William looks around the room. Dread everywhere. Settling into shock, Dwight watches his shotgun wound ble

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It’s funny- hurts less than the...uh, arrow... Hope Nods to William. He backs towards the door.

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (calmly, to William) Leave the gun. You can just wipe it off... My car is down the road, off in the woods a little. It’s dark though. Chris nervously shifts her weight as William runs past an out the door, gun still in hand. Dwight, Hope and Chris stand listening to the PAT OF WILL FEET AGAINST THE DIRT ROAD. Until they stand in silence.  94.

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He’s my Father’s son? Chris and Hope find each other’s eyes.

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Teddy told me about the cancer. Big Wade.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: (quiet, furious) Don’t you mention their names. Dwight pulls out the nickel plated revolver and sets it o the window ledge to his side.

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: You know what’s awful? He raises the Circuit Judge.

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Just because my Dad and your Mom loved each other? We all end up dead... Eyes glistening, lip trembling, DWIGHT LOWERS THE BARREL.

dialogues.speaker: HOPE CHARGES DWIGHT. DWIGHT AIMS AND FIRES.
dialogues.text: BOOM. HOPE’S LEG SPEWS BLOODY CHUNKS- IT DOESN’T SLOW HER DOWN ONE BIT. UNDERNEATH THE RECLINER’S EXTENDED FOOTREST: A HOMEMADE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DWIGHT BLASTS A HOLE IN CHRIS’ SHOULDER, SHATTERING THE L BY THE DOOR.

dialogues.speaker: ILLUMINATED BY RAPID GUNFIRE
dialogues.text: TEC-9 RIPS APART HOPE’S BACK AS SHE REACHES DWIGHT.  250 251 252 253 95. ON DWIGHT, CALMLY FIRING.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: William watches from the dark woods holding the shotgun. The Cleland home is ABLAZE IN GUNFIRE. Within seconds, it falls QUIET. William turns to the front gate, tossing the shotgun befo disappearing into the darkness. Just the DRONE OF THOSE BUSY NIGHT CREATURES.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The DRONE carries inside. The room is A DARK, BLOODY MESS. CLOSE ON DWIGHT. He sets his chin atop the window sill, unable to focus his gaze beyond the glass pane. WITH HEAVY BREATH, he tucks his neck until his forehead r on the sill and his eyes stare down at the shag carpet.

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: (gurgling) Keys are in the car. The keys are -..in the car... His words are overtaken by blood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Cleland property sits still in the night. Can’t see Dwight.

dialogues.speaker: A TRANQUIL SUBURBAN SOUNDSCAPE.
dialogues.text: KIDS ON BICYCLES pass a BENT CARBON ARROW by a sewer drai Another ARROW, EMBEDDED IN AN OAK TREE. Just behind it, a oblivious NEIGHBOR cleaning his gutters.  254 255 256 96.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON THE GARBAGE: Dwight’s CARDBOARD BOX sits atop the pile along with a few bird droppings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: IN THE KITCHEN: the TAPED UP CARDBOARD on the back window UNDER THE DINING TABLE: The GARDEN WEEDER lies in a pool sunlight. THE SOUND OF SOMEONE APPROACHING FROM OUTSIDE. ON THE FRONT DOOR: The Mail slot swings open, fluttering daylight as a STACK OF MAIL shoves through. ON THE FLOOR: SAM’S HOUSE KEYS, 4 days worth of JUNK MAIL and a POSTCARD, with a drawing of Thomas Jefferson’s home outlined block letters filled-in with images of lighthous waterfalls, blue mountains and trees.

dialogues.speaker: IT READS
dialogues.text: ‘Greetings from Virginia: The Old Dominion State’
